content.question: On a clear night, a Cargolux 777 freighter takes-off from King Khalid International Airport in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. A short time after lift-off, climb performance is significantly worsened. What is the probable reason?

options.D: Contamination such as sand and dust reducing engine performance

key_points: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear
Temperature inversion is defined as a condition where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude
Strong inversions are known to happen in desert areas, such as Saudi Arabia, where the surface will heat up quickly during the day and cool off rapidly at night
learning.explanation: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear. Temperature inversion is defined as a condition where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude. Strong inversions are known to happen in desert areas, such as Saudi Arabia, where the surface will heat up quickly during the day and cool off rapidly at night. Due to the temperature inversion, vertical mixing is inhibited - meaning that below an inversion, the wind speed will be light, and the wind just above the inversion may be relatively strong => wind shear develops between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above. This wind shear can cause airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft climbs or descends through the inversion. - Depending on the direction that the pilot decides to take off, the wind shift, at the top of the inversion, may change the headwind into a tailwind => which causes IAS to decrease - leading to a decrease in Rate of Climb. The fluctuation in airspeed can also induce a stall precariously close to the ground. - Furthermore, all performance is based on density altitude and temperature is a key factor. The higher the temperature, the higher the density altitude, the thinner the air and the less performance from your engines (and wings, etc). Since, as we climb through an inversion, temperature increases with an increase in height => we will experience a decreases aircrafts performance leading to a decrease in thrust and lift, as we climb into warmer and less dense air - which reduces the aircraft's rate of climb.

The most severe turbulence associated with Mountain waves can occur in the Rotor Zone, lying beneath the crests of lee waves - often marked by Rotor/roll clouds

The most powerful rotor lies beneath the first wave crest (one wavelength downwind) These waves are generated when: Wind direction: generally perpendicular (+/-30º) fashion, raised up over the mountains
learning.explanation: MOUNTAIN/LEE WAVES/STANDING WAVES develop on the lee, or downwind, side of mountains. The most severe turbulence associated with Mountain waves can occur in the Rotor Zone, lying beneath the crests of lee waves - often marked by Rotor/roll clouds. The most powerful rotor lies beneath the first wave crest (one wavelength downwind) These waves are generated when: Wind direction: generally perpendicular (+/-30º) fashion, raised up over the mountains. And no significant change in direction with altitude. Wind speed: strong. At least 20 kt, increasing with altitude, at the summits. Marked layer of stability/strong inversion around altitude of summits – which will work as a barrier over the mountains. Cloud Formation associated with Mountain Waves Lenticular clouds (lens shaped clouds) can form in the crest of the mountain waves. Rotor/Roll Clouds can also occur in the rotors below the waves. Cap clouds form on the ridge and strong winds may sweep the cloud down the lee slopes. - These clouds are a good indication of the presence of mountain waves but, if the air is dry, there may not be any cloud to see.

content.question: When established on the final approach path, and after passing below a cloud associated with a microburst, an aircraft can experience..

key_points: A Microburst is a localized column of sinking air (downdraft) within a thunderstorm
These also move outwards by reaction from the ground
The windshear (headwind to tailwind) may be between 50 and 90 kt
learning.explanation: A Microburst is a localized column of sinking air (downdraft) within a thunderstorm. These also move outwards by reaction from the ground. The windshear (headwind to tailwind) may be between 50 and 90 kt. Microbursts are short-lived, usually lasting less than 5 minutes, and they are relatively compact, usually affecting an area of 1 to 4 km in diameter. Flying through a Microburst 1. Imagine you're approaching a microburst at 80 knots. As you enter the vortex ring, you experience turbulence and a rapid increase in airspeed as you pick up a headwind. You start to climb as your performance increases. 2. As you enter the strongest part of the horizontal shaft, your airspeed peaks at 100 knots, an increase of 20 knots. You're still climbing as you enter the downdraft. 3. Inside the downdraft, your headwind starts to switch to a tailwind. You're caught in the downdraft, sinking quickly toward the ground. Your airspeed begins to decrease. 4. As you exit the downdraft, your tailwind increases rapidly. The shear drops your airspeed to 60 knots, which is 20 knots below your original speed. You're at a high angle-of-attack, and still descending. 5. You encounter more turbulence as you enter the final vortex. If you haven't already hit the ground, you may begin to climb again as you exit the vortex. => An airplane flying through a series of horizontal vortices generated by microbursts experiences alternating updrafts and downdrafts causing pitch changes without pilot input.

content.question: Which of the following is most likely to occur in a cold air pool?

key_points: COLD AIR POOL Cold air pools often form in topographic depressions, such as a valleys or basins, filled with cold air
The cold air is heavy and settles to the bottom of the depression

This air can remain stagnant, trapped by the surrounding higher terrain, resulting in long periods of poor air quality and fog, depending on the sources of pollution and amount of moisture in the air, respectively
learning.explanation: COLD AIR POOL Cold air pools often form in topographic depressions, such as a valleys or basins, filled with cold air. The cold air is heavy and settles to the bottom of the depression. This air can remain stagnant, trapped by the surrounding higher terrain, resulting in long periods of poor air quality and fog, depending on the sources of pollution and amount of moisture in the air, respectively. Where the temperature increases with an increase in height, then we have what is called a temperature inversion: vertical mixing is inhibited and below an inversion the wind speed will be light with a significantly different direction to the much stronger wind above the inversion. Hence windshear will occur at the inversion. An aircraft climbing or descending through the inversion will experience a rapid change in speed and direction which can lead to turbulence. Note: A Cold Air Pool is not the same as a "Cold Pool/Cold Air Drop".

content.question: Just after a flight, an aircraft is parked outside on the apron, where it is being refuelled. Freezing drizzle starts to fall. On which surfaces will ice accretion take the longest time?

options.A: Just above the fuel tanks and engines.
options.B: Areas above the spars and the main landing gear doubler plate.
options.C: The wing root area between the front and rear spars.
options.D: Wing leading edges, slats and flaps.

key_points: Where fuel tanks are coated by the wings of the aircraft, the temperature of the fuel greatly affects the temperature of the wing surface above and below these tanks
After a long flight, the temperature of an aircraft may be considerably lower than ambient temperature and therefore clear ice may form on wing areas above fuel tanks
To avoid the cold soaked phenomenon, skin temperature should be increased
learning.explanation: Where fuel tanks are coated by the wings of the aircraft, the temperature of the fuel greatly affects the temperature of the wing surface above and below these tanks. After a long flight, the temperature of an aircraft may be considerably lower than ambient temperature and therefore clear ice may form on wing areas above fuel tanks. To avoid the cold soaked phenomenon, skin temperature should be increased. Skin temperature can be increased by refueling with warm fuel. Adding (relatively) warm fuel to the aircraft can melt dry falling snow/freezing drizzle. The areas most vulnerable to freezing are: • The wing root area between the front and rear spars; • Any part of the wing that contains unused fuel after flight; • The areas where different wing structures are concentrated (a lot of cold metal), such as areas above the spars and the main landing gear doubler plate.

content.question: In winter, after breaking through a low level inversion during descent and assuming the pilot does not intervene,

options.A: lift most likely will increase and visibility is likely to improve.
options.B: thrust most likely will decrease and visibility is likely to improve.
options.C: lift most likely will decrease and visibility is likely to deteriorate.
options.D: thrust most likely will increase and visibility is likely to deteriorate.

key_points: In the standard atmosphere temperature decreases with altitude
Where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude (in the troposphere), then we have what is called an inversion
We can think of an inversion as a "Tupperware lid" for the atmosphere - it limits the upward movement of air from lower parts of the atmosphere (inhbits vertical mixing)
learning.explanation: In the standard atmosphere temperature decreases with altitude. Where the temperature increases with an increase in altitude (in the troposphere), then we have what is called an inversion. We can think of an inversion as a "Tupperware lid" for the atmosphere - it limits the upward movement of air from lower parts of the atmosphere (inhbits vertical mixing). Consequently, air pollutants, smoke, and dust aren't able to be dispersed throughout the atmosphere. This accumulation of particulates can cause reduced visibility below the inversion. With regards to this question, as we have discussed, as we descend through an inversion, temperature decreases with a decrease in height => Thrust and lift will increase as the aircraft descends into colder and denser air. Air pollutants, smoke, and dust will not disperse vertically, instead they are trapped below the inversion - resulting in a deteriorated visibility.

content.question: Which of these statements is correct regarding the difference between atmospheric turbulence and wind shear.

options.A: Atmospheric turbulence is the result of short duration and irregular movements of air from the undisturbed wind flow, whereas wind shear is caused by sudden and sustained changes in the wind direction and/or speed within a short distance.
options.B: Wind shear and atmospheric turbulence are the same thing and both result from sustained changes in the wind direction and/or speed, however, when the changes are frequent enough to displace an aircraft from its intended flight path they are described as wind shear.
options.C: Irregular short-period oscillations in the wind flow are the main cause of atmospheric turbulence, and when the turbulence is strong enough to cause fluctuations in aircraft airspeed, and/or attitude, it is described as wind shear.
options.D: The short-duration gustiness caused by fluctuations in the normal wind flow is the main cause of wind shear; however, where the gustiness is sustained over longer periods it is described as atmospheric turbulence, and can occur at all levels in the atmosphere.

key_points: Wind shear is defined by the World Meteorological Organisation as ‘layers or columns of air, flowing with different velocities (i
e
speed and/or direction) to adjacent layers or columns’
learning.explanation: Wind shear is defined by the World Meteorological Organisation as ‘layers or columns of air, flowing with different velocities (i.e. speed and/or direction) to adjacent layers or columns’. This means that we only experience wind shear when changing from layer to layer (vertical wind shear) or column to column (horizontal wind shear). Therefore it is a sudden, semi permanent change which can feel like turbulence when it does occur. Turbulence, on the other hand, is a temporary, irregular change in the speed or direction of a small "pocket" of air due to things such as thermal convection, mechanical eddy currents from the uneven ground, wake turbulence from other aircraft, etc. These are transient effects, and is not like the sudden, semi permanent effect of windshear. Note: Very heavy turbulence is not described as windshear, they are different phenomena, but can feel a little similar.

content.question: Exercise caution when flying in the vicinity of temperature inversions...

options.A: Since light winds over the mountain but strong winds at the airport on the windward side may indicate high level wind shear.
options.B: When flying in the winter in the mountains, due to wind shear and reduced aircraft performance.
options.C: While evening cooling of the air above the valley causes high speed winds on the surface.
options.D: Due to small-scale density variations that cause turbulent mixing of the air.

key_points: Temperature inversions inhibit vertical mixing, resulting in light winds below the inversion layer and relatively strong winds just above it
This contrast in wind speeds creates wind shear, which can lead to airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft ascends or descends through the inversion
It's important to note that at the top of the inversion, the wind direction can shift by as much as 90º, and the wind speed can increase by up to 40 knots
learning.explanation: Temperature inversions inhibit vertical mixing, resulting in light winds below the inversion layer and relatively strong winds just above it. This contrast in wind speeds creates wind shear, which can lead to airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft ascends or descends through the inversion. It's important to note that at the top of the inversion, the wind direction can shift by as much as 90º, and the wind speed can increase by up to 40 knots. Additionally, aircraft performance is closely tied to density altitude, with temperature playing a crucial role. As temperature rises, density altitude increases, causing the air to become less dense. This, in turn, affects engine and wing performance. When climbing through an inversion, the temperature rises with altitude, resulting in reduced aircraft performance. This decrease in performance leads to lower thrust and lift as the aircraft enters warmer and less dense air.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Complete the following statement according to figure.
Mountain waves and rotors are expected at _____ and _____ respectively.

key_points: Mountain Waves = oscillations to the lee side (downwind) of high ground resulting from the disturbance in the horizontal air flow caused by the high ground
Mountain waves are the result of flowing air being forced to rise up the windward side of a mountain barrier, then as a result of certain atmospheric conditions, sinking down the leeward side
This develops a series of standing waves downstream from the barrier and may extend for hundreds of kilometres over clear areas of land and open water
learning.explanation: Mountain Waves = oscillations to the lee side (downwind) of high ground resulting from the disturbance in the horizontal air flow caused by the high ground. Mountain waves are the result of flowing air being forced to rise up the windward side of a mountain barrier, then as a result of certain atmospheric conditions, sinking down the leeward side. This develops a series of standing waves downstream from the barrier and may extend for hundreds of kilometres over clear areas of land and open water. The wavelength and amplitude of the oscillations depends on many factors including the height of the high ground relative to surrounding terrain, the wind speed and the instability of the atmosphere. Mountain waves may also be referred to as standing waves or lee waves. These are likely to form when the following atmospheric conditions are present: Wind direction within 30 degrees of the perpendicular to the ridge of high ground and no change in direction over a significant height band. Wind speeds at the crest of the ridge in excess of 20 knots, increasing with height. A marked layer of stability around the altitude of the summits, e.g. an isothermal layer or inversion, with less stable air above and below If the wave amplitude is large enough, then the waves become unstable and break, similar to the breaking waves seen in the surf. Within these 'breaking waves', the atmospheric flow becomes turbulent. Vertical currents within the oscillations can reach 4,000 ft/min. The combination of these strong vertical currents and surface friction may cause rotors to form beneath the mountain waves causing severe turbulence.

"Its speed is decreasing rapidly with height" = wind speed is decreasing rapidly as height increases On the approach we will experience the opposite - headwind will increase rapidly as we descend

learning.explanation: A few considerations: Landing on Runway 330 (Northwesterly direction) with Northwesterly wind => we will experience Headwind. learning.explanation: MIXED ICE. Rain within or falling from clouds can consist of many different sized drops which may result in the formation of a mixture of clear and rime ice. content.question: The pilot of a small single-engine piston aircraft is preparing for a flight in winter. For the outside check, the pilot should be aware that the greatest risk of airframe ice build-up is when...

options.A: visible moisture is present with any ambient air or airframe temperature.
options.B: water in liquid form is present, with an ambient air temperature and airframe temperature below 0ºC.
options.C: snow or hail are falling, with an ambient air temperature above 0ºC.
options.D: the air is clear, with an ambient air temperature and airframe temperature below 0ºC.

key_points: A pilot must make sure that the airframe is clear of icing before departure, and this is a common problem during winter operations
Airframe icing on the ground is similar to in-flight icing, in that the water droplets need some reason to freeze onto the airframe

For starters, water needs to be present (visible moisture is another term for this), and there needs to be a component that is below 0ºC, whether that be the air, the airframe itself (often the case on a winter's morning), or the water droplets (SCWDs - Super-cooled water droplets, water that exists in a liquid form below 0ºC)
learning.explanation: A pilot must make sure that the airframe is clear of icing before departure, and this is a common problem during winter operations. Airframe icing on the ground is similar to in-flight icing, in that the water droplets need some reason to freeze onto the airframe. For starters, water needs to be present (visible moisture is another term for this), and there needs to be a component that is below 0ºC, whether that be the air, the airframe itself (often the case on a winter's morning), or the water droplets (SCWDs - Super-cooled water droplets, water that exists in a liquid form below 0ºC). The worst icing occurs when the airframe is cold and water or rain droplets freeze directly onto it, creating hard lumps on the wing that destroy the wing's airflow on take-off. There are other types of icing that can happen to an aircraft on the ground. In fact, hoar frost can be quite common, particularly if an airframe is very cold and the air contains a high relative humidity, allowing the water vapour to turn straight into ice crystals on the airframe by deposition (the opposite of sublimation). Even considering this, there is still only one good answer here.

content.question: What can result in the appearance of supercooled water droplets in the form of freezing rain?

options.A: Negative temperatures from FL300 to the ground.

key_points: FREEZING RAIN
The conditions needed for freezing rain are quite specific

learning.explanation: FREEZING RAIN. The conditions needed for freezing rain are quite specific. Generally, precipitation first falls from a cloud as snow. If it falls through warmer air before reaching the ground, it can melt and turn to rain droplets. If it then falls through cold air again before hitting the ground, the droplets can become supercooled (which means that they are still falling in liquid state, even though their temperature is below 0ºC). Freezing rain is a rare type of liquid precipitation that strikes a surface and freezes almost instantly. Most favourable conditions for the formation of freezing rain: Temperature inversions (with continuous rain) - Rain falls from a cloud at a temperature just above freezing into air with a temperature just below freezing. (Warm air aloft) Warm fronts: continuous rain falling from NS ahead of a warm front, flying from the cold sector into the warm sector. Occlusions

content.question: A thick layer of stratocumulus clouds is observed in a winter day in northern Europe where the temperature is close to 0°C at ground level. What can you expect?

options.A: A high probability for icing in clouds. Severe icing in the upper part due to accumulation of large droplets.
options.B: Turbulence due to a strong inversion, but no icing because clouds consist of ice crystals.
options.C: Decreasing visibility due to snowfall below cloud base, but only light icing in clouds.
options.D: Reduced visibility and light icing in clouds.

key_points: ICING
Some of the factors affecting the severity and the type of icing that occurs: Size of supercooled water droplets
The larger the supercooled water droplets, the greater the intensity of icing
learning.explanation: ICING. Some of the factors affecting the severity and the type of icing that occurs: Size of supercooled water droplets. The larger the supercooled water droplets, the greater the intensity of icing. Large supercooled water droplets can be found: Freezing Rain FZRA CU and CBs NS Concentration of water droplets. The higher the concentration, the greater the intensity of icing. Concentration is highest in convective clouds – CU and CB - and NS. Air temperature. Dictated what size of super-cooled water droplets will be present in a given cloud and also in what quantity. In this case, it is true that Stratocumulus clouds primarily contain small sized water droplets. However, bear in mind that temperature is very important. Temperatures at the surface are quite cold in this case (close to 0 °C). The cloud top will typically exhibit the coldest temperatures in these clouds. When the temperature is just right, these harmless-looking clouds can surprise a pilot with some moderate or even severe icing while climbing or descending through them – especially at the top of the cloud where the concentration of super-cooled water droplets will be higher. The higher the concentration of super-cooled water droplets, the greater the intensity of icing. Even though it's more common to observe light/moderate icing conditions in SC clouds, in extreme conditions, as the one depicted in the question, severe icing may occur.

content.question: What creates Ice crystal icing?

options.A: Sublimation of ice with regards to CB clouds.
options.C: It is created when vapour hits below 0ºC surfaces.
options.D: It is most present in NS clouds at very low temperatures.

key_points: Ice crystal icing (ICI) condition refers to aircraft experiencing icing inflight in high altitude due to high concentration of small ice crystals
At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology)
Several engine power-loss and damage events have occurred in convective weather above the altitudes typically associated with icing conditions
learning.explanation: Ice crystal icing (ICI) condition refers to aircraft experiencing icing inflight in high altitude due to high concentration of small ice crystals. At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology). Several engine power-loss and damage events have occurred in convective weather above the altitudes typically associated with icing conditions. Research has shown that strong convective weather (thunderstorm activity) can lift high concentrations of moisture to high altitudes where it can freeze into very small ice crystal. Ice crystals do not adhere to cold airframe surfaces because the ice crystals bounce off. However, the crystals can partially melt and stick to relatively warm engine surfaces.

content.question: A pilot is planning to depart from an airfield at sea level in the southern hemisphere below a layer of nimbo-stratus cloud with ceiling 5000 ft, the surface temperature at the airfield is +3°C, +7°C at the cloud ceiling, and it is raining. The aircraft`s initial track will be towards a nearby mountain range. Which of the following phenomena might indicate a risk of icing outside of the cloud shortly after take-off?

options.A: A SIGMET reporting severe turbulence in the lower levels of the atmosphere associated with the nearby mountains.
options.B: The forecast northerly wind backing with altitude and becoming easterly.
options.C: The dew point being reported as below the temperature at the airfield.
options.D: A temperature inversion aloft between 2000 ft and 5000 ft where the temperature at 2000 ft is -4°C.

key_points: Surface temperature is +3ºC and temperature at 5000 ft is +7ºC
We can say that there is a temperature inversion
An inversion is a reversal of the normal behaviour of temperature in the troposphere - where temperature increases with an increase in height
learning.explanation: Surface temperature is +3ºC and temperature at 5000 ft is +7ºC. We can say that there is a temperature inversion. An inversion is a reversal of the normal behaviour of temperature in the troposphere - where temperature increases with an increase in height. content.question: In order to avoid the associated hazards when circumnavigating a severe thunderstorm using airborne weather radar, what is the minimum distance from echoes that the aircraft should fly?

key_points: THUNDERSTORM AVOIDANCE Avoid thunderstorms by at least 20 NM => this general guideline applies even to jet fighters and large airliners
Hail and severe turbulence can exist well outside of the storm cloud
If you plan to deviate around a thunderstorm => fly on the upwind side so that your path does not converge with the path of the storm
learning.explanation: THUNDERSTORM AVOIDANCE Avoid thunderstorms by at least 20 NM => this general guideline applies even to jet fighters and large airliners. Hail and severe turbulence can exist well outside of the storm cloud. If you plan to deviate around a thunderstorm => fly on the upwind side so that your path does not converge with the path of the storm. Do not be tempted to try to fly under a thunderstorm, even if you can see through the rain on the other side => besides rain, hail and lighting, the area under a thunderstorm typically contains severe turbulence (including microbursts, windshear and downdrafts Trying to fly over a developing storm is also dangerous => the rising clouds can usually outclimb your aircraft. If your aircraft is equipped with a weather avoidance system, such as a weather radar, you can use it to avoid thunderstorms. You should avoid intense thunderstorms echoes by at least 20 NM. Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation. Therefore, do not try to use it to avoid instrument weather associated with clouds and fog – it does not provide any assurance of avoiding IFR weather conditions. Furthermore, as discussed above, Airborne Weather radar detects large droplet precipitation and hail (present in CBs), it does not detect stratus/stratocumulus or very small water droplets => making it relatively easy to identify embedded cumulonimbus. According to ICAO AC 120-88A Appendix 1: AVOID any convective activity (CBs) en route by at least 20 nautical miles.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The type of lightning shown in the picture is...

key_points: LIGHTNING As a towering cumulus develops, a large electrical charge separation builds up within the cloud
Lighting results when this electrical charge becomes strong enough to jump from the cloud to the ground, to another cloud, or to an opposite electrical charge within the same cloud
In the early stages of development, air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground
learning.explanation: LIGHTNING As a towering cumulus develops, a large electrical charge separation builds up within the cloud. Lighting results when this electrical charge becomes strong enough to jump from the cloud to the ground, to another cloud, or to an opposite electrical charge within the same cloud. In the early stages of development, air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground. When the opposite charges build up enough, this insulating capacity of the air breaks down and there is a rapid discharge of electricity that we know as lightning. Types of lightning: Intra-Cloud lightning: The most common type of lightning. It happens inside the cloud, jumping between different charge regions in the cloud. Cloud-to-air lightning: Referring to a discharge (or a portion of a discharge) jumping from a cloud into clear air. This happens when negative charged air particles become attracted to positive charges within a cloud. Cloud-to-cloud lightning: Happens when a negatively charged cloud finds a positively charged cloud and opposites attract. The discharge travels from cloud to cloud. Cloud-to-ground lightning: Occurs between the cloud and the ground.

A difference of wind speed of 20 kts between two relatively close sensors is a large indicator that wind shear is present, which is often caused by local weather systems such as thunderstorms, microbursts, etc

learning.explanation: It is not clear whether this is a vertical wind shear, or if it is horizontal wind shear (the wind is much stronger to the NE of the airfield), but in reality it does not matter. A difference of wind speed of 20 kts between two relatively close sensors is a large indicator that wind shear is present, which is often caused by local weather systems such as thunderstorms, microbursts, etc. The downdrafts from a thunderstorm/microburst hit the ground with a large amount of speed, then spreading out sideways, causing strong squalls of wind that are extremely localised, meaning that they can arrive and disappear very quickly, causing significant change to an aircraft's air speed. "An active anticyclone over the airfield" Incorrect. In the center of an anticyclone, one can anticipate a broad region of gentle and variable winds.

learning.explanation: Rain with a negative outside air temperature => Supercooled rain/Freezing rain, which consists of rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures. Freezing Rain can cause significant accumulations of clear ice. Clear ice is the most hazardous form of airframe icing. The raindrops spread and freeze on contact with a cold airframe. When the supercooled drop hits the airframe, it freezes relatively slowly due to the latent heat released in the freezing process. This allows part of the drop to spread backwards before it too freezes. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Clear ice forms a sheet of solid, clear, glazed ice with very little air trapped in it which can dramatically alter the aerodynamic properties of an aerofoil. There may also be a significant increased weight penalty associated with clear ice.

content.question: An aeroplane is flying in the lower stratosphere. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the general conditions in that area?

options.A: Horizontal movement of air masses is much less than in the troposphere, therefore very little head- or tailwind is to be expected.
options.B: The air in the lower stratosphere is very dry. Therefore, there are very few clouds in the stratosphere.
options.C: There is strong vertical movement of air masses and therefore more turbulence to be expected in the lower stratosphere than would be felt in the troposphere.
options.D: The temperature in the lower stratosphere decreases with height. This leads to reduced fuel consumption and better range.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.09.07.01.02: List the influences of the phenomena associated with the lower stratosphere (wind, temperature, air density, turbulence). In the stratosphere, which is the layer of atmosphere above the troposphere, starting at 36 090 ft in the International Standard Atmosphere (ISA), the temperature stays the same (isothermal layer) up to around 60 000 ft, where it then begins to gradually increase again. The lower levels of the stratosphere would therefore be around the region of 36 000 ft to 50 000 ft. Let's go through each option individually: A) "Horizontal movement of air masses is much less than in the troposphere, therefore very little head- or tailwind is to be expected." The wind in the lower stratosphere is still plenty strong enough to cause significant head- or tailwinds. The jetstreams sometimes extend upwards above the tropopause, and therefore this answer is wrong. B) "The air in the lower stratosphere is very dry. Therefore, there are very few clouds in the stratosphere." Indeed, the air is very dry in the stratosphere, especially as it is so cold, so cannot hold much water vapour at all. This, and the stability of the isothermal layer, make clouds very rare in the stratosphere. Correct. C) "There is strong vertical movement of air masses and therefore more turbulence to be expected in the lower stratosphere than would be felt in the troposphere." The stratosphere is isothermal, and is therefore stable. Rising air therefore stops at the tropopause, and there is very little vertical movement of air above this point (in comparison to the troposphere. Therefore there is little turbulence in the stratosphere. D) "The temperature in the lower stratosphere decreases with height. This leads to reduced fuel consumption and better range." As mentioned earlier, the temperature stays the same in the stratosphere until about 60 000 ft, where it gradually begins to become warmer again. The reduced fuel consumption and better range bit is actually correct, but for the wrong reason.

key_points: Refer to figure VALLEY INVERSIONS form as a result of both cooling of the ground due to long-wave radiation and nocturnal down-slope winds
They usually extend from the bottom of the valley up to the boundary-layer top
In winter, inversions can last for a few days to several weeks, being triggered and maintained by anticyclonic conditions at synoptic scale
learning.explanation: Refer to figure VALLEY INVERSIONS form as a result of both cooling of the ground due to long-wave radiation and nocturnal down-slope winds. They usually extend from the bottom of the valley up to the boundary-layer top. In winter, inversions can last for a few days to several weeks, being triggered and maintained by anticyclonic conditions at synoptic scale. How does a Valley Inversion form? The temperature of the upper parts of the valleys in mountainous areas becomes exceedingly low during winter nights because of radid loss of heat from the surface through terrestrial radiation. Consequently, the colder and heavier air of the upper part of the valley descends along the mountain slopes. The temperature of the valley floor does not fall considerably because of comparatively low rate of loss of heat aloft and hence this warmer and lighter air of the valley floor is pushed upwards by the cold downslope winds. Thus, there is warm air aloft and cold air in the valley floor and a temperature inversion is caused. Above the inversion, wind direction and speed may change significantly. Consequently, when crossing the top of the inversion, strong windshear (from 30 to 50 kt) may be expected.

content.question: An aircraft in the cruise is flying in stratiform cloud that covers an extensive area at the minimum safe altitude. If icing conditions are experienced, the best solution to avoid ice accretion is to..

options.A: climb to a higher flight level.

key_points: In-flight Ice Avoidance When ice formation is observed in flight, there is only one certain method of avoiding its hazards and that is to get out of the ice-forming layer as quickly as possible

Icing layers in stratus clouds with a vertical thickness in excess of 3000 feet are rare, so a change of altitude of a few thousand feet may take the aircraft out of icing - This is, by far, better than selecting a new track due to its widespread in the horizontal
This may be done by climbing above the ice forming zone or to descend and fly contact below the ice forming zone
learning.explanation: In-flight Ice Avoidance When ice formation is observed in flight, there is only one certain method of avoiding its hazards and that is to get out of the ice-forming layer as quickly as possible. Icing layers in stratus clouds with a vertical thickness in excess of 3000 feet are rare, so a change of altitude of a few thousand feet may take the aircraft out of icing - This is, by far, better than selecting a new track due to its widespread in the horizontal. This may be done by climbing above the ice forming zone or to descend and fly contact below the ice forming zone. The advisability of this course would depend on the ceiling and visibility along the route at the lower level concerned. In this case, the stratiform cloud is at the minimum safe altitude => therefore, a climb to a higher level should be considered. Do not remain in icing conditions any longer than necessary. For that reason, during climbs or descents through a layer in which icing conditions exist, plan your ascent or descent to be in the layer for as short a time as possible. Note: "increase the speed". Speed of an airplane affects accretion of ice. The faster an airplane moves through an area of supercooled water drops, the more moisture it encounters and the faster will be the accumulation of ice.

content.question: Ice accretion to the airframe is likely to be most hazardous at temperatures

key_points: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems
There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds

In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface
learning.explanation: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems. There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. It has an opaque appearance caused by air being trapped in water droplets as they freeze. Because it freezes instantly, it builds up on the leading edge of airfoils and it does not flow back over the wing. CLEAR ICE Can develop in areas of large water droplets that are found in cumulus clouds or in freezing rain beneath a warm front inversion. In this case, the droplets flow over the aircraft structure and slowly freeze (they can glaze the aircraft’s surface). Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -15ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Note: You are least likely to encounter icing in high clouds, because these clouds consist of ice crystals and this already-frozen moisture will not adhere to your airframe. Icing might also occur as a mixture of both rime and clear. TEMPERATURE RANGE TYPE OF ICING RIME ICE (Small supercooled water droplets Stratiform clouds) 0ºC TO -15ºC -15ºC TO -30ºC Expect moderate icing Expect light icing CLEAR ICE (Large supercooled water droplets Cumuliform clouds) 0ºC TO -15ºC May be found in CB’s at -25ºC Expect severe icing

Given the following METAR for a Spanish aerodrome in September, an hour before sunset; at what distance might a pilot expect to see the threshold of runway 26 whilst on final approach?

learning.explanation: Haze is traditionally an atmospheric phenomenon in which dust, smoke, and other dry particulates obscure the clarity of the sky. The increase in airborne particulates combined with low sun angles causes the slant range visibility to be reduced even further. content.question: Your departure aerodrome lies at the bottom of a valley in the mountains. Overnight, with clear skies, the wind has started to blow down the mountainside. The air temperature at 1 000 ft AGL is +2°C. What temperature could be expected at the airport just after sunrise?

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.09.08.03.0: Describe the formation of a valley inversion due to katabatic winds. A katabatic wind is what happens when the face of a mountain cools down, and then cools the air in contact with it. The colder air wants to sink, and creates a wind that flows down the mountainside into the valley below (if one exists). Very simply, this cold katabatic wind gathers in the bottom of a valley, creating what is called a valley inversion, where the air is cold at the ground level, but warms up as you gain altitude initially, into the air mass which has been displaced by the katabatic wind. It is extremely common for this to happen overnight in mountainous areas, and should be carefully considered, as it can reduce an aircraft's climb performance after take-off, which would be a bad effect in the region of mountains. Therefore, at the ground just after sunrise (the coldest time of day), we would expect the air in the valley to be colder than the air at 1000 ft, which means -1°C is the correct answer

learning.explanation: Sometimes thunderstorms will produce intense downdrafts that create damaging winds on the ground. Microbursts are short-lived, usually lasting less than 5 minutes, and they are relatively compact, usually affecting an area of 1 to 4 km in diameter. Microbursts are most likely to occur in summer air mass thunderstorms in low latitudes where the surface conditions are dry - causing extreme turbulence and severe windshear conditions. - A Macroburst is a similar even but affect a larger area - with a diameter of more than 4 km.

Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Clear ice forms a sheet of solid, clear, glazed ice with very little air trapped in it which can dramatically alter the aerodynamic properties of an aerofoil. There may also be a significant increased weight penalty associated with clear ice. Freezing Rain occurs when precipitation, in the form of rain, passes from a warm air mass into a relative cold air mass of an air temperature less than 0°C. The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled. These supercooled water droplets freeze when they come into contact with the ground or other exposed surface, if the surface temperature is below 0°C. "Snow" INCORRECT. Snow is solid precipitation in the form of ice crystals. Remember that for airframe icing to form water must be present in liquid state. "Cirrus Clouds" INCORRECT. You are least likely to encounter icing in high clouds, because these clouds consist of ice crystals and this already-frozen moisture will not adhere to your airframe.

content.question: What are the main hazards associated with Ice Crystal Icing (ICI)?

options.A: Obstructed visibility due to high accretion of ice on the windshield.
options.B: Engine malfunction and air data probes' obstruction.
options.C: Clear ice on the wings or rotorblades.

key_points: ICE CRYSTAL ICING Ice crystals phenomenon has only recently been identified as a serious threat to turbine engines
Ice crystals previously were thought to be harmless to airplanes because they will not adhere to the external airframe, and will simply bounce off the airframe without accreting

Nowadays, researchers believe that ice crystals can partially melt, due to compression effects, as they pass through the engine fan section, enter the engine core and create a film of moisture on relatively warm surfaces, such as the forward stator vanes
learning.explanation: ICE CRYSTAL ICING Ice crystals phenomenon has only recently been identified as a serious threat to turbine engines. Ice crystals previously were thought to be harmless to airplanes because they will not adhere to the external airframe, and will simply bounce off the airframe without accreting. Nowadays, researchers believe that ice crystals can partially melt, due to compression effects, as they pass through the engine fan section, enter the engine core and create a film of moisture on relatively warm surfaces, such as the forward stator vanes. The moisture traps additional ice crystals, and, eventually, the ice buildup is shed into the compressor, causing the engine to surge and stall and possibly the combustor, causing a flameout. Another possible cue to the presence of a high concentration of ice crystals at altitude is anomalous total air temperature (TAT) indications, which include the increase in outside static air temperature due to compression. Researchers believe that erratic and erraneously warm TAT indications are caused by ice crystals that build up on heated TAT probes and block the airflow through the probes.

content.question:
The crew get the ATIS for their destination aerodrome, which is summarised as follows:
Temperature: -18ºC
Dew point: -24ºC
Wind: Calm
Temperature inversion present
Which of the following may be a flight hazard in this situation?

options.A: The altimeter will overread the aerodrome elevation when the QNH is set.

key_points: If an indication of a temperature inversion is given as part of an ATIS, it means that it is quite a noticeable inversion
Inversions occur when the air gets warmer with increased altitude, so when warmer air is above colder air
This can happen for many reasons, due to night cooling, valley inversions, frontal activity, etc
learning.explanation: If an indication of a temperature inversion is given as part of an ATIS, it means that it is quite a noticeable inversion. Inversions occur when the air gets warmer with increased altitude, so when warmer air is above colder air. This can happen for many reasons, due to night cooling, valley inversions, frontal activity, etc. An inversion is incredibly stable, meaning that there is very little vertical movement of air through the inversion. This means that little to no mixing occurs, and therefore, the wind velocity (speed and direction) below the inversion may be totally different from the wind velocity above the inversion, and the difference may happen over a very small band of altitude. This means that flying through an inversion has the potential for quite significant vertical wind shear (changing wind velocity with changing altitude). This is why information about them are passed to pilots, so they can expect the wind shear and make decisions based on it. Inversions can also have large effects on aircraft performance, and the aircraft performance will be better below the inversion in the colder air. To look at the options: "The altimeter will overread the aerodrome elevation when the QNH is set." This is not correct, as the QNH pressure is set at aerodrome elevation, so will read the correct altitude when on the ground. The air is very cold so some temperature errors will exist when flying around, but as mentioned above, not when using QNH whilst on the ground. "Reduced braking performance." The ATIS said nothing about a wet or contaminated runway, braking performance might be perfectly fine. "Low visibility due to snow." The ATIS made no mention of snow. "Low level wind shear." Correct. As mentioned above, the inversion may cause wind shear at low levels when passing through it.

key_points: St
Elmo's fire is a phenomenon characterized by a luminous glow appearing around objects such as ship masts, aircraft wings, or even tree branches during thunderstorms or turbulent weather conditions
This phenomenon occurs when there is a buildup of static electricity in the air surrounding these objects
learning.explanation: St. Elmo's fire is a phenomenon characterized by a luminous glow appearing around objects such as ship masts, aircraft wings, or even tree branches during thunderstorms or turbulent weather conditions. This phenomenon occurs when there is a buildup of static electricity in the air surrounding these objects. As the air becomes charged, the electric field intensifies, causing electrons to ionize the air molecules. This ionization process generates a faint, bluish or violet glow, which can be observed especially at night or in low-light conditions. In the case of aircraft, St. Elmo's fire often manifests as a glowing halo around the edges of the cockpit windows, along the leading edges of the wings, or at the tips of the aircraft antennas.

key_points: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems
There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds

In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface
learning.explanation: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems. There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. It has an opaque appearance caused by air being trapped in water droplets as they freeze. Because it freezes instantly, it builds up on the leading edge of airfoils and it does not flow back over the wing. CLEAR ICE Can develop in areas of large water droplets that are found in cumulus clouds or in freezing rain beneath a warm front inversion. In this case, the droplets flow over the aircraft structure and slowly freeze (they can glaze the aircraft’s surface). Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -10ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Wings that are thin or have sharp leading edges are more efficient ice collectors. For this reason, smaller, thin airfoils may accrete more ice faster than larger, thick airfoils. => Therefore, severe icing accretion is most likely to occur in thin aerofoils and in the presence of large supercooled water droplets.

learning.explanation: THUNDERSTORM SUPERCELL The most severe type of single-cell thunderstorms are known as Supercell and have a long lifespan (6 to 8 hours), if the environment is favourable. Supercells are accompanied by severe weather phenomena like hail, extreme turbulence, downbursts or even tornadoes. They start to form in the same way as single-cell thunderstorms do, however the necessary conditions are more fully fulfilled and associated with appropriate vertical wind shear that creates rotational updraft. Although supercells require some degree of buoyancy, moderate to strong speed and directional wind shear between the surface and about 20 000 feet is the most critical factor. Wind shear not only creates the mesocyclone, but it also allows the storm to be tilted, which is important for maintaining a separate updraft and downdraft region.

content.question: What is the primary source of information for determining the presence and intensity of clear air turbulence (CAT)?

learning.explanation: Clear air turbulence (CAT) refers to turbulence occurring in cloud-free air. Unlike convective turbulence, CAT is invisible and may lack obvious signs of its presence. Consequently, the associated turbulence can catch individuals off guard. CAT can be severe, leading to structural damage, physical harm to both crew and passengers, and even impairing crew performance to the extent that simple tasks like reading instruments become nearly impossible. While NASA is actively developing various programs to enhance weather forecasting, the remote sensing of turbulence, especially CAT, using satellites remains a challenge, limiting the accuracy of forecasts. During flight, the most reliable source of information on turbulence is the reports provided by pilots. It is crucial for pilots to report turbulence so that air traffic control (ATC) can issue advisories to other aircraft and provide requested information. Aircraft reports (AIREPs) are particularly valuable since they can indicate the presence of CAT if turbulence is reported by another aircraft flying along the same route. This information assists in determining the potential location of CAT.

learning.explanation: LIGHTNING As a towering cumulus develops, a large electrical charge separation builds up within the cloud. Lighting results when this electrical charge becomes strong enough to jump from the cloud to the ground, to another cloud, or to an opposite electrical charge within the same cloud. In the early stages of development, air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground. When the opposite charges build up enough, this insulating capacity of the air breaks down and there is a rapid discharge of electricity that we know as lightning. Types of lightning: Intra-Cloud lightning: The most common type of lightning. It happens inside the cloud, jumping between different charge regions in the cloud. It lights up the cloud to look like the picture above. Cloud-to-air lightning: Referring to a discharge (or a portion of a discharge) jumping from a cloud into clear air. This happens when negative charged air particles become attracted to positive charges within a cloud. Cloud-to-cloud lightning: Happens when a negatively charged cloud finds a positively charged cloud and opposites attract. The discharge travels from cloud to cloud. Cloud-to-ground lightning: Occurs between the cloud and the ground.

key_points: An aircraft flying through an inversion, such as during take-off or landing, may experience significant changes in performance due to variations in air mass temperature

learning.explanation: An aircraft flying through an inversion, such as during take-off or landing, may experience significant changes in performance due to variations in air mass temperature. Depending on the take-off direction, the wind shift at the top of the inversion can turn a headwind into a tailwind, causing IAS to decrease, which in turn reduces the rate of climb. The resulting airspeed fluctuations can also increase the risk of a stall, especially when the aircraft is close to the ground. Additionally, aircraft performance is heavily influenced by density altitude, with temperature being a key factor. Higher temperatures increase the density altitude, resulting in thinner air and reduced engine and wing performance. As the aircraft climbs through an inversion where the temperature rises with altitude, performance decreases due to reduced thrust and lift, thereby lowering the rate of climb. The temperature inversion inhibits vertical mixing, leading to light winds below the inversion and relatively strong winds just above it. This creates wind shear between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above, which can cause airspeed fluctuations as the aircraft climbs or descends through the inversion.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The red dotted line shows the track crossing a front. There is a cold front with CBs up to FL370. The cruising altitude is FL360, and the maximum altitude is FL380. What is the best course of action?

options.A: It is safe to fly straight through the cold front at FL360 and keep the flight plan route. Only up to moderate turbulence can be expected within the cloud tops, without further hazards for flight safety.
options.B: Climb to FL380 to fly above the cold front. Moderate to severe turbulence can be expected within the CB cells, but only light turbulence above the CB cells.
options.C: Use the airborne weather radar and visual cues to circumnavigate the CB cells. Turbulence can be expected circumnavigating the CB cells.
options.D: Descend to FL280 to increase the margin for manoeuvring and avoid severe turbulence. Request help from ATC to find a safe path through the front, as they have better weather radar equipment.

key_points: Turbulence is commonly encountered within Cumulonimbus (CB) clouds due to their powerful vertical currents
These currents draw in air from the surrounding areas, generating turbulence as the air is displaced
Additionally, the energy from the rising air within the cloud can propagate turbulence above the cloud
learning.explanation: Turbulence is commonly encountered within Cumulonimbus (CB) clouds due to their powerful vertical currents. These currents draw in air from the surrounding areas, generating turbulence as the air is displaced. Additionally, the energy from the rising air within the cloud can propagate turbulence above the cloud. Beneath the cloud, the inflow and outflow of air produce severe turbulence at low altitudes, posing a significant risk, particularly with the potential occurrence of microbursts or downbursts, which can be life-threatening. Whenever feasible, it's preferable to perform lateral avoidance over vertical avoidance, using the airborne weather radar and visual cues to navigate around CB cells. Vertical avoidance may not always be viable, especially at high altitudes, due to reduced safety margins and performance limitations. When identifying a "threat area" such as a CB cloud, the flight crew should aim to clear it laterally by a minimum of 20 NM whenever possible. A larger margin may be necessary if the convective clouds are highly dynamic or have rapid build-up speeds. If the flight path intersects multiple convective clouds, maintaining a minimum margin of 40 NM from each "threat area" is recommended. "Descend to FL280 to increase the margin for manoeuvring and avoid severe turbulence. Request help from ATC to find a safe path through the front, as they have better weather radar equipment." Incorrect. Avoid attempting to fly beneath a convective cloud due to potential hazards such as severe turbulence, windshear, microbursts, and hail. Descent toward the wider part of the CB should be avoided as it can lead to icing issues due to an increase in supercooled liquid water droplets. "Climb to FL380 to fly above the cold front. Moderate to severe turbulence can be expected within the CB cells, but only light turbulence above the CB cells." Incorrect. If flying over a convective cloud cannot be avoided, a vertical margin of at least 5000 ft must be maintained. In this case, it would surpass performance limitations.

Initially there is formation of clear ice which forms when supercooled drops or droplets come into contact with a surface and freeze slowly. This type of ice accretion is denser, harder, and more transparent than rime ice. It alters the aerodynamics of the aircraft's wings and poses a significant hazard to flight. Clear ice starts as dense translucent ice with the formation of white horns. Rime ice is a white opaque deposit with a light texture. It is caused by small, supercooled water droplets that freeze quickly. There is little or no flowback due to the speed of freezing, and therefore, the ice grows out from the leading edges and is compacted by the airstream.

key_points: Ice Crystal Icing risk arises during flights in convective weather, characterized by convective clouds with substantial vertical extent, such as Cumulonimbus clouds containing high ice water contents
Studies indicate that intense convective weather, particularly thunderstorm activity, can elevate concentrated moisture to higher altitudes, leading to the formation of minuscule ice crystals
These crystals have the potential to impact aircraft engines when navigating through convective weather
learning.explanation: Ice Crystal Icing risk arises during flights in convective weather, characterized by convective clouds with substantial vertical extent, such as Cumulonimbus clouds containing high ice water contents. Studies indicate that intense convective weather, particularly thunderstorm activity, can elevate concentrated moisture to higher altitudes, leading to the formation of minuscule ice crystals. These crystals have the potential to impact aircraft engines when navigating through convective weather. This phenomenon is not observed during flights in non-convective weather, specifically cirrus clouds. High-level cirriform clouds like cirrus (Ci), cirrostratus (Cs), or cirrocumulus (Cc) clouds have a low concentration of ice crystals and do not present a significant risk of icing or turbulence. Consequently, flying through cirriform clouds, as mentioned in the question, is considered safe, and does not pose risk of airframe and engine icing.

options.B: accretion of ice on the elevator due to the slipstream from the flaps.
options.C: potential accretion of ice aft of the ice-protection equipment.
options.D: ailerons freezing at the outer ends of the wing.

key_points: Freezing Rain occurs when precipitation, in the form of rain, passes from a warm air mass into a relative cold air mass of an air temperature less than 0°C
The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled
It can cause significant accumulations of Clear Ice
learning.explanation: Freezing Rain occurs when precipitation, in the form of rain, passes from a warm air mass into a relative cold air mass of an air temperature less than 0°C. The rain maintaining its liquid state in sub-zero temperatures renders it super-cooled. It can cause significant accumulations of Clear Ice. Clear ice is the most hazardous form of airframe icing, because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. When the supercooled drop hits the airframe, it freezes relatively slowly due to the latent heat released in the freezing process. This allows part of the drop to spread backwards before it too freezes. The fact that the supercooled drops spread back before freezing is especially dangerous because there is the risk of accretion of ice aft of the ice-protection equipment.

content.question: A night in January has been cold and clear. In the forenoon of the next day an airfield is in IMC due to fog which extends to a height of 700 ft. A heavily laden aircraft departs and, when breaking through the top of the fog, experiences temporary bumpiness and a sudden decrease in climb rate. Mark the answer that states the most probable reason for the altered aircraft performance.

options.A: The aircraft suffers reduced lift and thrust due to a temperature inversion at the top of the fog.
options.B: The aircraft is under influence of a mountain breeze (descending air from the surrounding hills due to the incident sunshine).
options.C: The additional weight gained by water which has been gathered on wings and fuselage during flight through the fog reduces the lift.
options.D: The water which has been gathered during flight through the fog modifies the aerodynamic properties of the aircraft, thus reducing lift.

key_points: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear
Be prepared to encounter this situation when taking off or landing in calm wind under clear skies within a few hours before or after sunrise

- How does it happen? Due to the temperature inversion, vertical mixing is inhibited - meaning that below an inversion, the wind speed will be light and the wind just above the inversion may be relatively strong => wind shear develops between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above
learning.explanation: On a night of clear skies with calm or light surface wind, a temperature inversion can form due to surface cooling - which can lead to windshear. Be prepared to encounter this situation when taking off or landing in calm wind under clear skies within a few hours before or after sunrise. - How does it happen? Due to the temperature inversion, vertical mixing is inhibited - meaning that below an inversion, the wind speed will be light and the wind just above the inversion may be relatively strong => wind shear develops between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above. This wind shear can cause airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft climbs or descends through the inversion. Furthermore, all performance is based on density altitude and temperature is a key factor. The higher the temperature, the higher the density altitude, the thinner the air and the less performance from your engines (and wings, etc). Since, as we climb through an inversion, temperature increases with an increase in height => we will experience a decreased aircraft performance, leading to a decrease in thrust and lift, as we climb into warmer and less dense air. SUMMARY: An inversion marks the boundary between layers of air having differing temperatures and to some extent density. This will result in an aircraft gaining lift, thrust and power when descending through an inversion with the reverse conditions when climbing.

key_points: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems
There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds

In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface
learning.explanation: Structural Icing It builds up on any exposed surface of an aircraft, causing loss of lift, an increase in weight, and control problems. There are 2 general types of structural icing: RIME ICE Normally encountered in stratiform clouds. In these clouds, continuous icing can be expected in the temperature range from 0ºC to -30ºC, and results from instantaneous freezing of small supercooled water droplets striking the aircraft’s surface. It has an opaque appearance caused by air being trapped in water droplets as they freeze. Because it freezes instantly, it builds up on the leading edge of airfoils and it does not flow back over the wing. CLEAR ICE Can develop in areas of large water droplets that are found in cumulus clouds or in freezing rain beneath a warm front inversion. In this case, the droplets flow over the aircraft structure and slowly freeze (they can glaze the aircraft’s surface). Clear icing is most heavily concentrated in cumuliform clouds (dense clouds) in the range of temperature from 0ºC to -10ºC. However, you can encounter clear icing in Cumulonimbus clouds with temperatures as low as -25ºC. In addition, supercooled water and icing have been encountered in thunderstorms as high as 40 000 ft, with temperatures of -40ºC. Clear ice is the most serious of the various forms of ice because it has the fastest rate of accumulation and is more difficult to remove than rime ice. Note: You are least likely to encounter icing in high clouds, because these clouds consist of ice crystals and this already-frozen moisture will not adhere to your airframe. Icing might also occur as a mixture of both rime and clear. At -25ºC, we can expect light icing.

key_points: HOAR FROST It occurs when a sub-zero surface comes into contact with moist air (the ambient temperature is lowered to saturation level)
It is a white crystal deposit which appears similar to frost on the ground
Hoar frost can occur in clear air
learning.explanation: HOAR FROST It occurs when a sub-zero surface comes into contact with moist air (the ambient temperature is lowered to saturation level). It is a white crystal deposit which appears similar to frost on the ground. Hoar frost can occur in clear air. Water vapour in contact with the airframe is converted to ice crystals without becoming liquid (sublimating). This whole process required the presence of another type of ice nucleus – their composition is usually inorganic (ie. Dust, soil particles). Hoar frost can occur: on the ground. This usually occurs at night and is similar to the frost which forms on a car. If frost is not removed from the wings before flight, it can cause an early airflow separation that decreases lift and increases drag. This causes the airplane to stall at a lower-than-normal angle of attack. in flight. Hoar frost can occur in flight in the following cases: If a rapid descent is made from a very cold region to a warm moist layer. If a climb is made from a temperature below 0°C through an inversion. The icing is not severe. The effects can be overcome by flying in a region where the temperature is above 0°C or by flying faster to increase the kinetic heating. "Haze is a reduction of visibility due to the presence of water vapour" INCORRECT. Haze is an atmospheric phenomenon in which dust, smoke, and other dry particulates obscure the clarity of the sky - it is not caused by water particles. "Mountain waves are always accompanied by rotor clouds" INCORRECT. Mountain waves are accompanied by rotor clouds only if sufficient moisture is present in the air.

content.question: High ice crystal concentrations and ice crystal icing is usually the result of:

options.A: Large amounts of condensation in a convective storm producing large water droplets which then freeze into large snowflakes in the upper levels of clouds.
options.B: Weak convection concentrates moisture in the lower parts of clouds where condensation creates small supercooled water droplets or ice crystals.
options.C: Strong convective activity lifting large concentrations of moisture to high altitudes where sublimation then creates very small ice crystals.
options.D: Strong up-currents that allow large ice crystals to develop through collision and coalescence from small ice crystals.

key_points: Ice crystal icing (ICI) condition refers to aircraft experiencing icing inflight in high altitude due to high concentration of small ice crystals
At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology)
Engine surfaces and pitot tubes are affected
learning.explanation: Ice crystal icing (ICI) condition refers to aircraft experiencing icing inflight in high altitude due to high concentration of small ice crystals. At very low temperatures, the water vapour turns directly into solid ice crystals by deposition (often referred to as "sublimation" in meteorology). Engine surfaces and pitot tubes are affected. Several engine power-loss and damage events have occurred in convective weather above the altitudes typically associated with icing conditions. Research has shown that strong convective weather (thunderstorm activity) can lift high concentrations of moisture to high altitudes where it can freeze into very small ice crystal. Ice crystals do not adhere to cold airframe surfaces because the ice crystals bounce off. However, the crystals can partially melt and stick to relatively warm engine surfaces. It has also been noted that ice crystals impacting heated windscreens can result in pilots observing “rain” as the crystals rapidly melt on contact with the heated windscreen. The main risk of encountering high crystal concentrations appears to be downwind from the tops of large areas of convective cloud - the area where the visible anvil shape is seen when viewed from a distance.

content.question: Prior to arriving at an airport after sunset, an ATIS reports calm surface winds, temperature -18°C, dew point -24°C, and a 15°C inversion at 300 ft above aerodrome level. What flight safety risk can be expected, based on that ATIS?

options.A: The possibility for a sudden reduction in visibility due to the blowing snow.
options.B: A sudden degradation of braking performance on the runway.
options.D: The altimeter will over-read the aerodrome elevation.

key_points: Note: This is very similar to question 502742
We do not yet know if the questions and options are the same, or if the wordings are different, and we believe there may be two questions present, perhaps by different authorities
Nonetheless, the answer should be the same, as the scenario is almost exactly the same
learning.explanation: Note: This is very similar to question 502742. We do not yet know if the questions and options are the same, or if the wordings are different, and we believe there may be two questions present, perhaps by different authorities. Nonetheless, the answer should be the same, as the scenario is almost exactly the same. Please let us know if you see these in the exam, and anything you can remember about the question(s) that you see, thank you! If an indication of a temperature inversion is given as part of an ATIS, it means that it is quite a noticeable inversion. Inversions occur when the air gets warmer with increased altitude, so when warmer air is above colder air. This can happen for many reasons, due to night cooling, valley inversions, frontal activity, etc. An inversion is incredibly stable, meaning that there is very little vertical movement of air through the inversion. This means that little to no mixing occurs, and therefore, the wind velocity (speed and direction) below the inversion may be totally different from the wind velocity above the inversion, and the difference may happen over a very small band of altitude. This means that flying through an inversion has the potential for quite significant vertical wind shear (changing wind velocity with changing altitude). This is why information about them are passed to pilots, so they can expect the wind shear and make decisions based on it. Inversions can also have large effects on aircraft performance, and the aircraft performance will be better below the inversion in the colder air. To look at the options: "The possibility for a sudden reduction in visibility due to the blowing snow." The ATIS made no mention of snow. "A sudden degradation of braking performance on the runway." The ATIS said nothing about a wet or contaminated runway, braking performance might be perfectly fine. The low air temperature has the opportunity to form ice from any moisture, but if the ground if dry then the traction should not be much less than normal. "Possibility for low-altitude wind shear." Correct. As mentioned above, the inversion may cause wind shear at low levels when passing through it. "The altimeter will over-read the aerodrome elevation." This is not necessarily correct, as if the QNH pressure is set at aerodrome elevation, the altimeter will read the correct altitude when on the ground. The air is very cold so some temperature errors will exist when flying around, but as mentioned above, not if using QNH. This is because the QNH is measured at the aerodrome elevation specifically so the elevation will show on aircraft altimeters when they are on the ground.

content.question: Flying an aircraft that is certified for flight in known icing, the crew are choosing a route to give the lowest possibility of airframe icing. Which of the following routes should they choose?

options.A: A route with snow and rain.

key_points: In flight airframe icing occurs when an aircraft flies through icing conditions
Icing conditions are mostly present within clouds below freezing temperature (0ºC), where the suspended water droplets have not yet become ice crystals
These droplets are held in a "supercooled" state, in that their temperature is less than 0ºC, but they are still liquid
learning.explanation: In flight airframe icing occurs when an aircraft flies through icing conditions. Icing conditions are mostly present within clouds below freezing temperature (0ºC), where the suspended water droplets have not yet become ice crystals. These droplets are held in a "supercooled" state, in that their temperature is less than 0ºC, but they are still liquid. We call them Supercooled Water Droplets (SCWDs). When an aircraft flies through a cloud of SCWDs, some of them will hit the airframe (which is also below freezing temperature), and this will cause the droplets to freeze, adhering to the airframe in the process. This can form icing such as rime ice, clear ice, or mixed ice (a mixture of the two). This can occur in precipitation also, particularly when the air temperature or airframe is below 0ºC, where rain, freezing rain, or wet snow can adhere to the airframe or engines. In reality, the best option here is "dry snow", as dry snow is considered to be made up of solid ice crystals only, not any water droplets that could freeze onto the wing. Therefore, dry snow is very unlikely to adhere to the wing, unlike the other options. Even "snow and rain" has a higher chance of causing airframe icing than dry snow, as the temperature will be very close to 0ºC in this instance, and the airframe or air temperature may be intermittently below 0ºC, causing ice accretion. The other two options are obviously very likely to cause problematic ice accretion.
