learning.explanation: Upper Wind and Temperature Chart One thing all upper air charts have in common are the height lines (contours) themselves. These lines represent the altitude (in meters) of various significant pressure levels. On any given constant pressure chart, the air pressure is the same at all locations. Upper wind charts are issued for different pressure altitudes (eg 200hPa, 250hPa, 300hPa etc). Hence, the pressure is constant for the chart. The contours on the chart (called isohypses) join points of equal height for that pressure altitude and show where the air is colder/warmer (the higher the contour, the warmer the air is).

content.question:
(For this question use annex 050-027).
An aircraft is flying from Point A to Point B at the flight level corresponding to the pressure surface of the constant pressure chart. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.A: The true altitude will be higher over B than over A.
options.B: Wind speed over A is higher than over B.
options.C: Wind speed over Paris is higher than over B.
options.D: The true altitude will be higher over A than over B.

key_points: The chart shown is not a surface pressure chart, where the lines show points of equal pressure
It is a high altitude contour chart, where the same pressure (for instance 500 hPa) is assumed, and the exact height (above MSL) of that pressure level is plotted
This means the lines are points of equal height (isohypses) and the higher the pressure level is (the further that pressure level is from MSL), the higher the pressure is in that region
learning.explanation: The chart shown is not a surface pressure chart, where the lines show points of equal pressure. It is a high altitude contour chart, where the same pressure (for instance 500 hPa) is assumed, and the exact height (above MSL) of that pressure level is plotted. This means the lines are points of equal height (isohypses) and the higher the pressure level is (the further that pressure level is from MSL), the higher the pressure is in that region. It is a better way for meteorologists to plot upper winds and high altitude pressures, but for all we care, it acts very similar to a surface pressure chart. The wind circulates anticlockwise around a low, and clockwise around a high in the Northern Hemisphere. The closer the isobars/isohypses, the higher the wind speed. With regards to this question, We can see that this question depicts a situation in the Northern Hemisphere, in Paris. Now, notice the wind arrow on the lower right side of "A", which indicates that the wind is blowing from the Southwest, therefore indicating an anticlockwise direction => which means that it is a low pressure area. This means we can label the isohypses in our mind, and give each one an arbitrary number, if necessary, to indicate its height or pressure. All we are looking to do is to work out if B is higher or lower pressure than A, so we have labelled it as if it were a surface pressure chart, for ease. The values don't matter, only the relationship. We can see that the left hand pressure system is a low, and following the wind along the isobars/isohypses, that the right hand pressure system is also a low, and is a deeper low. By counting the isobars away from the left hand side and towards the right, we can see that the point B lies at a lower pressure area than the point A. "High to low, beware below", and therefore the true altitude of the aeroplane is higher at A and lower at B. Neither of the options regarding the wind speed are correct given that the closer the contour lines, the higher the wind speed.

TECHNICAL SPECIFICATIONS RELATED TO METEOROLOGICAL OBSERVATIONS AND REPORTS 2.3 Criteria for issuance of local special reports and SPECI 2.3.3 Recommendation.- Where required in accordance with Chapter 4, 4.4.2 b), SPECI should be issued whenever changes in accordance with the following criteria occur: a) When the wind changes through values of operational significance. The threshold values should be established by the meteorological authority in consultation with the appropriate ATS authority and the operators concerned, taking into account changes in the wind which would: 1) require a change in runway(s) in use; and 2) indicate that the runway tailwind and crosswind components have changed through values representing the main operating limits for typical aircraft operating at the aerodrome; b) When the visibility is improving and changes to or passes through one or more of the following values, or when the visibility is deteriorating and passes through one or more of the following values: 1) 800, 1 500 or 3 000 m; and 2) 5 000 m, in cases where significant numbers of flights are operated in accordance with the visual flight rules; Note 1. - In local special reports, visibility refers to the value(s) to be reported in accordance with 4.2.4.2 and 4.2.4.3; in SPECI, visibility refers to the value(s) to be reported in accordance with 4.2.4.4. Note 2. - Visibility refers to "prevailing visibility" except in the case where only the lowest visibility is reported in accordance with 4.2.4.4 b). c) When the runway visual range is improving and changes to or passes throough one or more of the following values, or when the runway visual range is deteriorating and passes through one or more of the following values: 50, 175, 300, 550 or 800 m; d) When the onset, cessation or change in intensity of any of the following weather phenomena occurs: - duststorm - sandstorm - funnel cloud (tornado or waterspout); e) When the onset or cessation of any of the following weather phenomena occurs: - low drifting dust, sand or snow - blowing dust, sand or snow - squall; f) when the height of base of the lowest cloud layer of BKN or OVC extent is lifting and changes to or passes through one or more of the following values, or when the height of base of the lowest cloud layer of BKN or OVC extent is lowering and passes through one or more of the following values: 1) 30, 60, 150 or 300 m (100, 200, 500 or 1 000 ft); and 2) 450 m (1 500 ft), in cases where significant numbers of flights are operated in accordance with the visual flight rules; g) When the sky is obscured and the vertical visibility is improving and changes to or passes through one or more of the following values, or when the vertical visibility is deteriorating and passes through one or more of the following values: 30, 60, 150 or 300 m (100, 200, 500 or 1 000 ft); and h) Any other criteria based on local aerodrome operating minima, as agreed between the meteorological authority and the operators concerned. Note.- Other criteria based on local aerodrome operating minima are to be considered in parallel with similar criteria for the inclusion of change groups and for the amendment of TAF developed in response to Appendix 5, 1.3.2 j). 2.3.4 When a deterioration of one weather element is accompanied by an improvement in another element, a single SPECI shall be issued; it shall then be treated as a deterioration report.

A knowledge of the radar principle is paramount in order to accurately tune this system and interpret the weather radar display correctly. Reflectivity Weather detection is based on the reflectivity of water droplets. The weather echo appears on the Navigation Display (ND) with a color scale that goes from red (high reflectivity) to green (low reflectivity). The weather radar echo returns vary in intensity as a function of the droplet size, composition and quantity. For example, a water particle is five times more reflective than an ice particle of the same size.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The images are examples of visible and infrared satellite images (valid for the same time). Using the satellite images, what type of clouds are present in a band stretching from the Gulf of Mexico northeastward into New York?

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.10.01.03.04: Interpret qualitatively the satellite pictures in order to get useful information for flights: location of clouds (distinguish between stratiform and cumuliform clouds). Visible (VIS) Images and Infrared (IR) have different ways of detecting clouds. VISIBLE (VIS) – Pictures from space; produced by sun rays reflecting off clouds. Advantages: easy to interpret, the clouds look the same as in real life. Disadvantage: not available continuously, due to the lack of sunlight at night. Clouds are represented in white, the land grey and the sea black. INFRARED (IR) – The temperature of the cloud will determine the wavelength of radiation emitted from the cloud, which can then be displayed. Advantages: available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will about the same by day and by night. Disadvantage: If the clouds near the surface are approx. same temperature as the land surface it can be difficult to distinguish the clouds from land. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image. Together, they can give us a good idea of what clouds are present. In this case, the band of clouds is very white on the IR image, so we know that the cloud tops are very cold (high in the atmosphere). Also, the visible image shows us that the clouds are thick enough to obscure the land below, and not wispy like cirrus clouds might be. This means that the clouds are thick, with good vertical extent, so they must be cumulus/cumulonimbus clouds.

key_points: This question refers to a phenomenon called: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through
Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs
The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation
learning.explanation: This question refers to a phenomenon called: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through. Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs. The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation. In simple words, Radar attenuation is simply the absorption or reflection of radar signals as the radar pulse penetrates an area of precipitation, preventing that radar from detecting any additional cells that lie behind the first storm. Tip for avoiding shadows: To accurately interpret your radar returns, aim the tilt on your radar down far enough to paint the ground, then look for returns. If you see a potential shadow (a dark, blank area), look for a cell in front of the shadow. If you see a storm before the shadow, avoid it. If you don’t see any storm cells in front of the dark area, it’s probably not a shadow, but may be a large lake or a tall mountain (equally disturbing, depending on your altitude).

RVR is a special measure of visibility in the direction of the runway. As prevailing visibility is usually used, which is approximately the average visibility in all directions from the station, this can be a bit inaccurate, as the visibility can vary massively between two different directions, due to different density of obscuration, perhaps. This is why, when the visibility is below 1500 m, the RVR is reported also, as the RVR (Runway Visual Range) is a measure of the exact visibility directly down the runway, and usually is measured at 3 different places on the runway, touchdown zone, midpoint, and stop-end. This is almost always higher than the prevailing visibility, as it only has to consider the visibility in one direction. These days, it is automatically measured by devices alongside the runway, called transmissometers (the newer versions are called scatterometers). In terms of this question, the runway visual range is often measured by counting the amount of centreline markings or lights that can be seen ahead of the aircraft, so those two answers must be correct. Also, the next closest answer is the runway edge lights, which you should be able to see also. The other options are either to the side of the runway (in a direction where visibility is not assured), or behind the aircraft when lined up. Again, we are not sure about some of the options here, due to lack of feedback.

content.question: What does a ground weather radar show overlaid on a map?

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.10.01.04.01: Describe the basic principle and the type of information given by a ground weather radar. Ground weather radars are similar to airborne weather radars. They operate using the same system of pulses and returns, including the use of doppler shift to calculate directions in some cases. They are dotted around many European countries to provide a good coverage, and indicate areas of precipitation, as well as the intensity of that precipitation. If you think about it, they are a very simple system. All they can do is beam out pulses and see which return, how strong the returns are and how far away they are returning from. They cannot measure visibility or obscurity (which are pretty much the same thing) as they are set up to measure precipitation, so are the wrong wavelength for tiny dust or water particles to provide returns. The returns also differ depending on the precipitation, but they can certainly measure differ intensities of precipitation, usually using the standard green-yellow-red colour scheme that we are familiar with.

key_points: The word VOLMET derives from the French words "vol" (flight) and "météo" (weather)
The purpose of a VOLMET broadcast is to provide weather information to aircraft in flight
VOLMET reports are broadcast principally over high frequency (HF) radio by a number of civil and military stations located around the world
learning.explanation: The word VOLMET derives from the French words "vol" (flight) and "météo" (weather). The purpose of a VOLMET broadcast is to provide weather information to aircraft in flight. VOLMET reports are broadcast principally over high frequency (HF) radio by a number of civil and military stations located around the world. This global network is divided into regions with each region having a number of VOLMET broadcast stations which all broadcast on the same frequency(s). In some regions, such as Europe, there are also a number of stations which provide VOLMET broadcasts on very high frequency (VHF) radio. In both cases, the station will use automated voice transmission to broadcast TAF, SIGMET and METAR information for a published list of aerodromes. VHF stations normally broadcast their information in a continuous loop updating the information as changes occur. HF VOLMET stations generally broadcast on a published schedule with five minute intervals allocated to each station, thus preventing overlapping transmission on the same frequency. A listing of VOLMET broadcasts by provider, inclusive of broadcast time, frequency(s) and a list of aerodromes for which information is provided, can be found in the appropriate en-route supplements for the region in question. With the ever increasing availability of SATCOM and Data Link equipment such as ACARS, the reliance on VOLMET is diminishing. None the less, it is anticipated that VOLMET stations will continue to broadcast inflight weather information in the coming years.

Thus, we can conclude that the geostrophic wind at position 45°N 030°W is blowing from the southwest. key_points: FEW CONSIDERATIONS: Firstly, it is important to point out that this is a Contour chart and pressure information is not provided - Pressure is constant everywhere => this shows the True Altitude of a certain pressure level
For example, the 500 hPa level corresponds to FL180

learning.explanation: FEW CONSIDERATIONS: Firstly, it is important to point out that this is a Contour chart and pressure information is not provided - Pressure is constant everywhere => this shows the True Altitude of a certain pressure level. For example, the 500 hPa level corresponds to FL180. Isohypses will show you whether its true altitude is found at a lower or higher level (due to temperature variations). Isohypses are are plotted with the reference being MSL and the heights give us an indication of the distance that a pressure level is from MSL. If the contours are high values (wider spaced) then we can assume a high pressure exists. Conversely if the contours are lower values (closely packed),then we can assume a low pressure. Having that established, it is true that roughly the same rules apply as for isobar charts. The closer the contours the stronger the wind. Circulation of air around a High and Low Pressure system: In the Northern Hemisphere: - The air moves anticlockwise around a low pressure centre; and - Clockwise around a high pressure centre. In the Southern Hemisphere: - The air moves clockwise around a low pressure centre; and - Anticlockwise around a high pressure centre. With regards to this question, We can see that this question depicts a situation in the Southern Hemisphere, in Melbourne. Now, notice the wind arrow on the upper left side of "A", which indicates that the wind is blowing from Southwest - Northeast, therefore indicating an clockwise direction => which means that both are low pressure areas. The tighter packed Isohypses show lower elevations, wider spaced isohypses show higher elevations => by looking at the isohypses, we can see that the contours at "A" are closer than at "B", therefore true altitude is higher over "B" than "A".

key_points: AIRBORNE WEATHER RADAR Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it
It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail)
Reflectivity Weather detection is based on the reflectivity of water droplets
learning.explanation: AIRBORNE WEATHER RADAR Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail). Reflectivity Weather detection is based on the reflectivity of water droplets. The weather echo appears on the Navigation Display (ND) with a color scale that goes from red (high reflectivity) to green (low reflectivity). The weather radar echo returns vary in intensity as a function of the droplet size, composition and quantity. => Airborne weather radars do not detect turbulence, although turbulent air, particularly within a thunderstorm, often contains water. In some modern radars, a change in frequency (a Doppler shift) in the reflected (returned) radar signal caused by moving precipitation is measured and is used to give an indication of likely turbulence. => This function (the TURB function) is based on the Doppler effect and is sensitive to precipitation movement. The TURB function is on most weather radars only active within a range of 40 NM (Doppler measurement capability) and should only be used in wet turbulence.

Which of these statements about weather satellites are correct or incorrect?
1. The pictures from geostationary weather satellites are generally of higher resolution than the pictures from satellites in a polar orbit
2. Satellites in a polar orbit are closer to the earth than geostationary satellites

key_points: There are two types of satellite - the Polar Orbiting and the Geostationary: Polar orbits take the satellites over the Earth’s poles
The satellites travel very close to the Earth (usually between 820 and 970 km above sea level), covering a band 1500 NM wide
Any spot on the globe will experience a southbound pass of the satellite in the morning and a northbound pass in the afternoon or evening
learning.explanation: There are two types of satellite - the Polar Orbiting and the Geostationary: Polar orbits take the satellites over the Earth’s poles. The satellites travel very close to the Earth (usually between 820 and 970 km above sea level), covering a band 1500 NM wide. Any spot on the globe will experience a southbound pass of the satellite in the morning and a northbound pass in the afternoon or evening. Although picture definition is good, polar orbiting satellites do not give a continuous view of the weather. Geostationary satellites take 24 hours to orbit the Earth, so the satellite appears to remain in the same part of the sky when viewed from the ground. These orbits are much higher than polar orbits (typically 36,000 km) so the satellites travel more slowly, at speeds of around 3 km/s. Picture definition may not be as good as Polar orbitting satellites images, but the advantage of a continuous picture outweighs this disadvantage. Because of the Equatorial orbit the picture becomes somewhat distorted towards the poles. 1 The pictures from geostationary weather satellites are generally of higher resolution than the pictures from satellites in a polar orbit. INCORRECT 2 Satellites in a polar orbit are closer to the earth than geostationary satellites. CORRECT

options.D: The depression centred at 54°N, 013°W (992 hPa) is moving rapidly south; southerly winds should be expected at the aerodrome.

key_points: To start, we must note that the chart is valid at midday on the 22nd, whereas the METAR is valid at 21:00 on the same day (222100Z), so the weather situation has had time to change over those 9 hours
The change in weather appears to be mostly a reduction in pressure, from approximately 1000 hPa or 1001 hPa from the isobars on the chart, to 995 hPa in the later METAR

This means that the low pressure zone to the North / North West of the aerodrome has most likely deepened and the associated trough has extended along the line of the cold front, which also does not appear to have passed by the time of the METAR observation (as the METAR would show rain or more clouds)
learning.explanation: To start, we must note that the chart is valid at midday on the 22nd, whereas the METAR is valid at 21:00 on the same day (222100Z), so the weather situation has had time to change over those 9 hours. The change in weather appears to be mostly a reduction in pressure, from approximately 1000 hPa or 1001 hPa from the isobars on the chart, to 995 hPa in the later METAR. This means that the low pressure zone to the North / North West of the aerodrome has most likely deepened and the associated trough has extended along the line of the cold front, which also does not appear to have passed by the time of the METAR observation (as the METAR would show rain or more clouds). There are also 2 fronts, so there is very little chance that both have already passed. Therefore, by the next morning (23rd), we are at the point that the cold front will begin to move in, and it now has an associated trough of low pressure, which is likely to bring increased rain, convective activity, windshear, turbulence, etc. To address some of the incorrect options, the wind in the morning would most likely be W or SW, changing to W or NW after the passage of the fronts/trough.

content.question: Which instrument is used to measure atmospheric humidity?

key_points: Atmospheric humidity can be measured using a psychrometer, a dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer or an electrical hygrometer
The psychrometer and the dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer use two thermometers to measure relative humidity; one measures the dry-bulb temperature and the other measures the wet-bulb temperature
The wet-bulb thermometer contains water in the base that evaporates and absorbs heat which decreases the temperature reading
learning.explanation: Atmospheric humidity can be measured using a psychrometer, a dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer or an electrical hygrometer. The psychrometer and the dry bulb and wet bulb hygrometer use two thermometers to measure relative humidity; one measures the dry-bulb temperature and the other measures the wet-bulb temperature. The wet-bulb thermometer contains water in the base that evaporates and absorbs heat which decreases the temperature reading. To determine the relative humidity, the temperatures are taken from the dry-bulb thermometer and the temperature difference between the wet and dry bulb thermometers. Note: "Pluviometer" is used for measuring the amount of precipitation at a given location over a specified period of time. "Transmissometer" is used to determine visibility and runway visual range.

An aircraft is flying from Point A to Point B at the flight level corresponding to the pressure surface of the constant pressure chart. Which of the following statements is correct?

key_points: FEW CONSIDERATIONS: Firstly, it is important to point out that this is a Contour chart and pressure information is not provided - Pressure is constant everywhere => this shows the True Altitude of a certain pressure level
For example, the 500 hPa level, in ISA conditions, corresponds to FL180
Isohypses will show you whether its true altitude is found at a lower or higher level (due to temperature variations)
learning.explanation: FEW CONSIDERATIONS: Firstly, it is important to point out that this is a Contour chart and pressure information is not provided - Pressure is constant everywhere => this shows the True Altitude of a certain pressure level. For example, the 500 hPa level, in ISA conditions, corresponds to FL180. Isohypses will show you whether its true altitude is found at a lower or higher level (due to temperature variations). Isohypses are are plotted with the reference being MSL and the heights give us an indication of the distance that a pressure level is from MSL. If the contours are high values (wider spaced) then we can assume a high pressure exists. Conversely if the contours are lower values (closely packed),then we can assume a low pressure. Having that established, it is true that roughly the same rules apply as for isobar charts. The closer the contours the stronger the wind. Circulation of air around a High and Low Pressure system: In the Northern Hemisphere: - The air moves anticlockwise around a low pressure centre; and - Clockwise around a high pressure centre. In the Southern Hemisphere: - The air moves clockwise around a low pressure centre; and - Anticlockwise around a high pressure centre. With regards to this question, We can see that this question depicts a situation in the Northern Hemisphere, in Paris. Now, notice the wind arrow on the lower right side of "A", which indicates that the wind is blowing from a Southerly direction, therefore indicating an anticlockwise direction => which means that both are low pressure areas. The tighter packed Isohypses show lower elevations, wider spaced isohypses show higher elevations => by looking at the isohypses, we can see that the contours at "B" are closer than at "A", therefore true altitude is higher over "A"/Paris than "B". Furthermore, as we have discussed, the contour lines are closer together at "B" than at "A"/Paris so the wind is stronger at "B" than at "A"/Paris

content.question: During the preparation for approach to Zurich airport (1 416 ft/AMSL) a pilot hears the following message on the ATIS: "Inversion warning. Inversion of 12°C between 1 900 ft and 2 300 ft altitude." This message indicates that the pilot should be prepared:

options.A: that the performance of the engine will be reduced from inversion level down to ground.
options.B: for wind shear just above the inversion.
options.D: for freezing precipitation below the inversion.

key_points: The air in the inversion layer between 1900 ft and 2300 ft is very much warmer than the air between the bottom of the inversion and the airfield at 1416 ft

Due to the temperature inversion, vertical mixing is inhibited - meaning that below an inversion, the wind speed will be light and the wind just above the inversion may be relatively strong => wind shear develops between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above
This wind shear can cause airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft climbs or descends through the inversion
learning.explanation: The air in the inversion layer between 1900 ft and 2300 ft is very much warmer than the air between the bottom of the inversion and the airfield at 1416 ft. Due to the temperature inversion, vertical mixing is inhibited - meaning that below an inversion, the wind speed will be light and the wind just above the inversion may be relatively strong => wind shear develops between the calm winds below and the stronger winds above. This wind shear can cause airspeed fluctuations as an aircraft climbs or descends through the inversion. The aircraft is most likely climbing after take off or approaching to land when passing through the inversion, which means that the airspeed is most probably slow - only a few knots greater than stall speed. The fluctuation in airspeed can induce a stall precariously close to the ground. "that the performance of the engine will be reduced from inversion level down to ground." INCORRECT. Below the inversion, temperature will decrease and pressure increase with decreasing altitude => engine performance will increase. "for fog below the inversion." INCORRECT. The information provided is not enough to conclude this. For fog to form, the air must be saturated, we would need to know at least temperature/dewpoint information.

Therefore, do not try to use it to avoid instrument weather associated with clouds and fog – it does not provide any assurance of avoiding IFR weather conditions
learning.explanation: AIRBORNE WEATHER RADAR Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail). Therefore, do not try to use it to avoid instrument weather associated with clouds and fog – it does not provide any assurance of avoiding IFR weather conditions. A knowledge of the radar principle is paramount in order to accurately tune this system and interpret the weather radar display correctly. Reflectivity Weather detection is based on the reflectivity of water droplets. The weather echo appears on the Navigation Display (ND) with a color scale that goes from red (high reflectivity) to green (low reflectivity). The weather radar echo returns vary in intensity as a function of the droplet size, composition and quantity. For example, a water particle is five times more reflective than an ice particle of the same size.

key_points: THUNDERSTORM (Cumulonimbus) AVOIDANCE Avoid thunderstorms by at least 20 NM => this general guideline applies even to jet fighters and large airliners
Hail and severe turbulence can exist well outside of the storm cloud
If you plan to deviate around a thunderstorm => fly on the upwind side so that your path does not converge with the path of the storm
learning.explanation: THUNDERSTORM (Cumulonimbus) AVOIDANCE Avoid thunderstorms by at least 20 NM => this general guideline applies even to jet fighters and large airliners. Hail and severe turbulence can exist well outside of the storm cloud. If you plan to deviate around a thunderstorm => fly on the upwind side so that your path does not converge with the path of the storm. Do not be tempted to try to fly under a thunderstorm, even if you can see through the rain on the other side => besides rain, hail and lighting, the area under a thunderstorm typically contains severe turbulence (including microbursts, windshear and downdrafts Trying to fly over a developing storm is also dangerous => the rising clouds can usually outclimb your aircraft. If your aircraft is equipped with a weather avoidance system, such as a weather radar, you can use it to avoid thunderstorms (CBs). Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail). Therefore, do not try to use it to avoid instrument weather associated with clouds and fog – it does not provide any assurance of avoiding IFR weather conditions. Furthermore, as discussed above, Airborne Weather radar detects large droplet precipitation and hail (present in CBs), it does not detect stratus/stratocumulus or very small water droplets => making it relatively easy to identify embedded cumulonimbus.

learning.explanation: Phrases such as "ahead of the front" and "behind the front" refer to the movement of weather fronts. Being "behind the cold front" indicates being inside the cold air mass, while being "ahead of the cold front" suggests being in the warm air mass displaced by the cold air mass as it moves. Cold fronts mark the leading edge of a cold air mass displacing a warmer air mass. They are illustrated by a blue line with triangles pointing in the direction of movement. A warm front is the leading edge of a warm air mass that is replacing a colder air mass. It is represented by a red line with half-moons indicating its direction of motion. learning.explanation: Wind velocity in a METAR is stated as the measured or estimated mean of each component over the 10 minutes prior to the time of issue of the METAR, unless there are significant variations during this 10 minute period. The definition of significant variations can be found in ICAO annex 3. ATIS wind velocity is latest 2 minute average. It is supplemented by the largest (and smallest) gusts within the last 10 minutes if they vary more than 10 knots from the average wind speed. Aerodrome Controller (ATC) given wind is also the latest 2 minute average, with broadly the same rules as the ATIS wind. The "instant wind" can also be given to an aircraft if requested or if the controller thinks it useful. All winds are measured by anenometers at 10 m above the ground, as that is the international standard for "surface wind".

content.question:
Refer to figure.
The pressure system at position "D" is a..

key_points: Col = A neutral area in the middle of two low and two high pressure systems
It is the point of intersection of a trough and a ridge on a weather map
The air pressure is slightly higher than that of the low-pressure (depression) regions, but lower than that of the high pressure (anticyclonic) regions
learning.explanation: Col = A neutral area in the middle of two low and two high pressure systems. It is the point of intersection of a trough and a ridge on a weather map. The air pressure is slightly higher than that of the low-pressure (depression) regions, but lower than that of the high pressure (anticyclonic) regions. Weather can be unsettled and can go for the worse or clear up, the winds are relatively calm and varying in direction. Trough = Extended region of a low-pressure system. Troughs may be at the surface, or aloft, or both under various conditions. Most troughs bring clouds, showers, and a wind shift, particularly following the passage of the trough. Troughs are very often associated with the fronts of polar front depressions. The weather associated with a trough will be similar to that of the depression/low pressure area. If they are not marked, troughs may still be identified as an extension of isobars away from a low-pressure system. They are often V-shaped Ridge = Extended region of a high-pressure system. The ridge originates in the centre of an anticyclone. The phenomenon is the opposite of a trough. Ridges of high pressure are indicated by isobars extending outwards from an anticyclone and always rounded, never V-shaped as seen in a trough. In case of this specific question: We can see that the pressure system at D lays between a high-pressure system east and west, and that there is a low-pressure system to the north and south. Because of this we can say that the pressure system at position D will be a col.

learning.explanation: Tropical Cyclone Advisory Information - Form of the code 1- Identification group: The report starts with the term "TC ADVISORY", which indicates that it is a tropical cyclone advisory. 2- Date and time of the issuance (abbreviated as "DTG"): The year, month, day, hours and minutes of the issuance are reported in UTC as "yyyymmdd/GGggZ". 3- Name of the TCAC (abbreviated as "TCAC"): The name of the TCAC that issued the report is given in a free text form. 4- Name of the tropical cyclone (abbreviated as "TC"): The name, or number of the cyclone is given. 5- Advisory number (abbreviated as NR): This number starts with "01" in the case of each cyclone. 6- Position of the centre (abbreviated as "PSN"): Geographical coordinates of the centre of the tropical cyclone given in degrees and minutes. 7- Directon and speed of the movement (abbreviated as "MOV"): If the tropical cylone moves slowly (moving at a speed lower than 3 kt), or it is stationary (moving at a speed lower than 1 kt), the abbreviations SLW or STNR are used, respectively. 8- Atmospheric pressure of the centre (abbreviated as "C"): Given in units of hPa. 9- Maximum surface wind (abbreviated as "MAX WIND") The maximum value of the surface wind near the centre over a 10 minute time period. 10- Forecast of the position of the centre and maximum wind (abbreviated as "FCST PSN" and "FCST MAX WIND"): This information is reported 6, 12, 18 and 24 hours after the time of observation. 11- Remarks (abbreviated as "RMK"). 12- The code groud "NXT MSG EXP indicates the date of the issuance of the next advisory. At which airport is the following weather development taking place?
TAF 060600Z 0607/0616 25006KT 8000 NSC BECMG 0613/0616 23016KT 4500 RA SCT030 OVC050=

key_points: Note that the chart is valid for 0600 UTC
TAF 060600Z 0607/0616 25006KT 8000 NSC BECMG 0613/0616 23016KT 4500 RA SCT030 OVC050= Period of validity is stated as 07:00 UTC until 16:00 UTC day 06 (0607/0616)

Initial weather conditions are forecasted to be: 25006KT = wind 250º at 6 kt 8000 = visibility 8000 m NSC = no significant clouds A change of permanent character is expected to occur on day 06 at any time between 13:00 and 16:00 (BECMG 0613/0616)
learning.explanation: Note that the chart is valid for 0600 UTC. TAF 060600Z 0607/0616 25006KT 8000 NSC BECMG 0613/0616 23016KT 4500 RA SCT030 OVC050= Period of validity is stated as 07:00 UTC until 16:00 UTC day 06 (0607/0616). Initial weather conditions are forecasted to be: 25006KT = wind 250º at 6 kt 8000 = visibility 8000 m NSC = no significant clouds A change of permanent character is expected to occur on day 06 at any time between 13:00 and 16:00 (BECMG 0613/0616). After the change occurs, the following conditions are to be expected: 23016KT = wind 230º at 16 kt 4500 = visibility 4500 m RA = moderate rain SCT030 = scattered clouds at 3000 ft OVC050 = overcast layer at 5000 ft From the above decoded TAF, we can see that the wind is gradually backing whilst the wind speed is increasing (250º/6kt - 230º/16 kt). Visibility deteriorates (from 8 km down to 4.5 km) due to moderate rain - most probably falling from Nimbostratus clouds. An overcast layer is also forecasted between 1300 UTC and 1600 UTC => typical conditions for an approaching warm front. The only airports situated ahead of a warm front are: EDDL and LFPO. "LFPO" is INCORRECT. Note that the map is valid for 0600 UTC and rain only starts at 1300 UTC (according to the TAF). At 0700 UTC, this airport would definitely be situated in the rain belt of the warm front and, therefore, rain should be in the forecast (for 0700 UTC) => and it is not. Furthermore, overcast layer of clouds would be expected just ahead of the warm front, with relatively low cloud bases. Instead, "no significant clouds" are forecasted for 0700 UTC. "EDDL" is CORRECT. Considering the TAF, we can expect the warm front to be quite far away from the airport at 0600 UTC. We can expect EDDL to be situated in the rain belt of the warm front at around 1100 UTC - it makes sense that rain is in the next forecast (for 1300 UTC), along with overcast clouds.

The lines and annotations show a reasonable interpretation of where the fronts and other features are, as follows: Symbol "a": approximate low pressure centre. Blue line: cold front associated with the low pressure system. Remember that a cold front is always drawn on the warm side of the frontal zone, so most of the frontal clouds appear just behind the front, as the cold airmass wedges under and lifts the warmer air ahead of it. Cold fronts usually extend quite far south from low pressure systems. Red line: warm front associated with the low pressure system. Remember that the warm front is also always drawn on the warm side of the frontal zone, so a lot of the clouds appear ahead of it, as the warm air rises up slowly over the cooler air ahead of it. Purple line: occluded front, which extends from the junction of the warm and cold fronts back towards the low centre. Occlusions typically occur where the cold airmass has caught up with the warm air and is under-riding it, so clouds also appear just ahead of the front.

learning.explanation: SATELLITE IMAGES, in meteorology, are primarily used to monitor the weather and climate of the Earth. Satellite images can often be used to help meteorologists forecasting the weather over the next 12, 24 and 36 hours. These will usually show the cloud patterns over an area. For example, a swirl of white cloud on an infrared satellite image often means that a depression is moving in. Satellites can be Polar Orbiting, covering the entire Earth and passing above or nearly above both poles, or Geostationary satellites, hovering over the Equator. There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared. => Apart from clouds and fog, satelite imagery can be used to identify other weather phenomenon, such as Low Pressure Systems and Fronts. Weather satellite images have also helped in monitoring volcanic ash clouds.

learning.explanation: In some instances, runway visibility information is given in a METAR; this is known as Runway Visual Range, RVR. The RVR group starts with the letter R, and then goes on to give the runway in use, followed by the threshold visibility in meters. If the RVR is more than the maximum reportable value of 1500 meters, the code P is used in front of the visibility value, R30/P1500. If the visibility is less than 50 m then the prefix M will be used, e.g. R30/M0050. A letter can sometimes come after the RVR to indicate any trends that the RVR has shown. A U means that the visibility has increased by 100 m or more in the last 10 minutes, e.g. R30/1100U. A D shows that visibility has decreased by 100 m or more in that same time period, R30/1100D. An N added to the visibility group shows that there is no distinct trend observed, R30/1100N.

key_points: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through
Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs
The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation
learning.explanation: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through. Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs. The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation. In simple words, Radar attenuation is simply the absorption or reflection of radar signals as the radar pulse penetrates an area of precipitation, preventing that radar from detecting any additional cells that lie behind the first storm. Tip for avoiding shadows: To accurately interpret your radar returns, aim the tilt on your radar down far enough to paint the ground, then look for returns. If you see a potential shadow (a dark, blank area), look for a cell in front of the shadow. If you see a storm before the shadow, avoid it. If you don’t see any storm cells in front of the dark area, it’s probably not a shadow, but may be a large lake or a tall mountain (equally disturbing, depending on your altitude).

learning.explanation: Visible (VIS) Images and Infrared (IR) have different ways of detecting clouds. For instance; VISIBLE (VIS) – Produced by sun rays reflecting off clouds. Advantages: easy to interpret Disadvantage: not available continuously, due to the lack of sunlight at night Clouds are represented in white, the land grey and the sea black. INFRARED (IR) – temperature of cloud will determine the wavelength of radiation emitted from the cloud. Advantages: available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will about the same by day and by night. Disadvantage: If the clouds near the surface are approx. same temperature as the land surface it can be difficult to distinguish the clouds from land. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image. If a cloud is seen on Visible (VIS) but very hard to see on Infrared (IR), then it could be a layer of fog or shallow stratus near the surface.

learning.explanation: Learning Objectives reference 050.10.02.04.01: State that numerical weather prediction uses a 3D grid of weather data, consisting of horizontal data (latitude-longitude) and vertical data (height or pressure). Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) To run numerical weather prediction models, meteorologists divide the Earth’s surface and atmosphere into a 3D grid called a global coordinate system. All weather data are mapped onto this grid with each grid box representing the atmospheric processes in that region. Atmospheric models can calculate winds, heat transfer, radiation, relative humidity, and surface hydrology within each grid and evaluate interactions within neighbouring points. Numerical prediction equations are applied to each box of the grid and across an aggregation of medium-range weather forecast some two to fifteen days ahead. The 3D grid consists of horizontal data (latitude-longitude) and vertical data (height or pressure).

(For this question use annex 050-029).
An aircraft is flying from Point A to Point B at the flight level corresponding to the pressure surface of the constant pressure chart. Which of the following statements is correct?

options.B: The true altitude will be higher over B than over A.
options.C: Wind speed over Madrid is higher than over A.
options.D: Wind speed over B is higher than over A.

key_points: FEW CONSIDERATIONS: Firstly, it is important to point out that this is a Contour chart and pressure information is not provided - Pressure is constant everywhere => this shows the True Altitude of a certain pressure level
For example, the 500 hPa level, in ISA conditions, corresponds to FL180
Isohypses will show you whether its true altitude is found at a lower or higher level (due to temperature variations)
learning.explanation: FEW CONSIDERATIONS: Firstly, it is important to point out that this is a Contour chart and pressure information is not provided - Pressure is constant everywhere => this shows the True Altitude of a certain pressure level. For example, the 500 hPa level, in ISA conditions, corresponds to FL180. Isohypses will show you whether its true altitude is found at a lower or higher level (due to temperature variations). Isohypses are are plotted with the reference being MSL and the heights give us an indication of the distance that a pressure level is from MSL. If the contours are high values (wider spaced) then we can assume a high pressure exists. Conversely if the contours are lower values (closely packed),then we can assume a low pressure. Having that established, it is true that roughly the same rules apply as for isobar charts. The closer the contours the stronger the wind. Circulation of air around a High and Low Pressure system: In the Northern Hemisphere: - The air moves anticlockwise around a low pressure centre; and - Clockwise around a high pressure centre. In the Southern Hemisphere: - The air moves clockwise around a low pressure centre; and - Anticlockwise around a high pressure centre. With regards to this question, We can see that this question depicts a situation in the Northern Hemisphere, in Madrid. Now, notice the wind arrow on the upper side of "B", which indicates that the wind is blowing from a Easterly direction, therefore indicating an anticlockwise direction => which means that both are low pressure areas. The tighter packed Isohypses show lower elevations, wider spaced isohypses show higher elevations => by looking at the isohypses, we can see that the contours at "A" are closer than at "B", therefore true altitude is higher over "B" than "A". Furthermore, as we have discussed, the contour lines are closer together at "A" than at "B", so the wind is stronger at "A" than at "B".

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which flight route exhibits the greatest variation in the height of the tropopause?

key_points: The tropopause marks the boundary between the troposphere and the stratosphere and is where temperature ceases to fall with an increase in height
The height of the tropopause is controlled by the temperature of the air near the surface
The warmer the air, the higher the tropopause
learning.explanation: The tropopause marks the boundary between the troposphere and the stratosphere and is where temperature ceases to fall with an increase in height. The height of the tropopause is controlled by the temperature of the air near the surface. The warmer the air, the higher the tropopause. The colder the air, the lower the tropopause. Therefore, temperature variations due to latitude, season, land and sea, will all cause varying heights of the tropopause. At the Equator, the average tropopause height ranges from 16 to 18 km, with temperatures averaging between -75°C and -80°C. Conversely, at the poles, the height is around 8 km, with average temperatures between -40°C and -50°C. Averaging at 50°N, the tropopause height is about 11 km (36 090 ft), accompanied by a temperature of approximately -56.5°C. We would usually recommend that you choose the route with the largest variation in latitude (so an elongated North/South route, but in this case, the correct answer appears to be based on the temperature at FL240 As we have been given the temperatures at FL240 (remember they are all negative numbers), then we can say that the greater the change in temp at FL240, the greater the change in tropopause height (it's a tiny bit of a stretch but still true in most cases), which allows us to answer the question. The greatest change in temperature at FL240 is from Keflavik to Brussels, Route 2, where the temperature changes from around -42ºC to -28ºC. Each other route has a much smaller temperature change.

There are four criteria which must be met in order for CAVOK to appear in the METAR
learning.explanation: The code CAVOK is frequently used in the METAR code, being the abbreviation for “cloud, ceiling and visibility are OK.” If CAVOK is used, it will replace the visibility, RVR, weather and cloud groups. There are four criteria which must be met in order for CAVOK to appear in the METAR. These are: the visibility must be 10 kilometers or more; the height of the lowest cloud must be no less than 5000 ft, or the level of highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater; there must be no cumulonimbus or ‘towering cumulus’ (TCU) present; there must be no significant weather at or in the vicinity of the aerodrome. Note: Minimum Sector Altitude is the lowest altitude that may be used under emergency conditions which will provide a minimum clearance of 1 000 ft above all objects located in an area contained within a sector of a circle of 25 NM radius centered on a radio navigation aid. options.B: Metres or/and Feet, according to Annex 3.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.10.01.01.11: List the units used for runway visual range (m, ft). This is one of three very similar questions (505494, 506338 and 507458). We think the current answer is the most correct out of the options given, but it is a little misleading, given that RVR is reported in feet in the USA. ICAO annex 3 defines RVR as follows: Runway visual range (RVR). The range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings or the lights delineating the runway or identifying its centre line. In METARs, the RVR values are prefixed by the letter “R”, followed by the runway number for which the RVR value applies and the actual RVR value. In annex 3, ICAO specifically dictate that RVR should be measured in metres, but some countries (like the USA) may choose to differ from this as long as they notify ICAO as such. For instance, The United States FAA dictate that there, RVR shall be measured in feet and reported in 100 ft intervals

For the purpose of this question, this Significant Weather Chart (SWC) mainly shows us the location of the jet stream and the height of the tropopause on either side of it. These can tell us enough to work out the expected temperature change in the cruise at FL310. We can see that the jet stream begins far North of Shannon and goes South of Amsterdam, and that would indicate that Amsterdam would be in the "cold sector" and Shannon within the "warm sector" of that polar front. Working out the temperature difference depends on the heights of the tropopause on either side of the polar front, as well as the height of the jet stream core. Up to the jet stream core altitude, the warm sector is warmer, it usually becomes equal around the height of the jet stream, and then becomes warmer in the stratosphere above the cold sector above this altitude. key_points: There are two types of satellite - the Polar Orbiting and the Geostationary: Polar orbits take the satellites over the Earth’s poles
The satellites travel very close to the Earth (usually between 820 and 970 km above sea level), covering a band 1500 NM wide
Any spot on the globe will experience a southbound pass of the satellite in the morning and a northbound pass in the afternoon or evening
learning.explanation: There are two types of satellite - the Polar Orbiting and the Geostationary: Polar orbits take the satellites over the Earth’s poles. The satellites travel very close to the Earth (usually between 820 and 970 km above sea level), covering a band 1500 NM wide. Any spot on the globe will experience a southbound pass of the satellite in the morning and a northbound pass in the afternoon or evening. Although picture definition is good, polar orbiting satellites do not give a continuous view of the weather. Geostationary satellites take 24 hours to orbit the Earth, so the satellite appears to remain in the same part of the sky when viewed from the ground. These orbits are much higher than polar orbits (typically 36,000 km) so the satellites travel more slowly, at speeds of around 3 km/s. Picture definition may not be as good as Polar orbitting satellites images, but the advantage of a continuous picture outweighs this disadvantage. Because of the Equatorial orbit the picture becomes somewhat distorted towards the poles.

learning.explanation: Visible (VIS) Images and Infrared (IR) have different ways of detecting clouds. For instance; VISIBLE (VIS) – Produced by sun rays reflecting off clouds. content.question:
Refer to figure.
You plan a 5 hour flight on 12th March 2017 from Hahn (H) (50°N,007°E) to Brest (B) (49°N,004°W), taking off at 17:00 UTC. The planned cruise altitude must be higher than 3 200 feet altitude. At what altitude must the aircraft fly to avoid moderate to severe icing?

options.D: You can't avoid icing on this route.

key_points: Whilst in the first half of the flight, the aircraft is in sector "D" of the chart
This sector shows isolated scattered/broken cumulus and stratocumulus - with moderate icing to the East of the sector, we are in the West of the sector so that does not affect us
We can expect moderate turbulence at 3 000 ft for this section of flight, but no icing
learning.explanation: Whilst in the first half of the flight, the aircraft is in sector "D" of the chart. This sector shows isolated scattered/broken cumulus and stratocumulus - with moderate icing to the East of the sector, we are in the West of the sector so that does not affect us. We can expect moderate turbulence at 3 000 ft for this section of flight, but no icing. In the second half of flight, we pass through sector "B" which has an occluded front followed by a slow moving cold/warm front reversal, so many different weather conditions can be expected in this area. In terms of icing, sector "B" contains cumulus and stratocumulus clouds which are overcast in the frontal areas between cloud bases of 1 500-3 000ft and tops of 5 000 - 8 000ft. The 0ºC level in sector "B" is between 4 000 ft and 6 000 ft, which could make the aircraft in non-icing conditions, however, convective activity such as that associated with fronts in this region can cause air movements that reduce the 0⁰C isotherm, and can cause icing in our case. Also, NASA quotes ice as being worst between +2⁰C and -20⁰C, so we know it can happen in low positive temperatures. The aircraft cannot therefore avoid icing conditions on that route at any of the given levels. Note: There is some debate over whether the aircraft could remain outside of icing conditions at 3 500 ft, as that is lower than the 0ºC isotherm in the B region, however, the CU/SC cloud that would be encountered does include moderate icing and turbulence, and icing can occur just above 0ºC, so we are agreeing with the most recent feedback that 3500 ft would not be able to avoid moderate icing.

learning.explanation: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection. There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared. Visible imagery is produced by the sun's rays reflecting off of clouds - which means that it is not available continuously, due to the lack of sunlight at night. Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black. Infrared imagery is produced by sensing the emitted radiation coming off of clouds. The temperature of the cloud will determine the wavelength of radiation emitted from the cloud. Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image.

learning.explanation: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection. There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared. Visual Images. Although visual photography may be easy to interpret, it suﬀers the disadvantage of not being available continuously, due to lack of sunlight at night. Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black - Visible satellite image show solid clouds (such as CBs) as bright white and wispy clouds (thin or faint cloud - such as cirrus) as translucent whitish layers. Infrared (IR). Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image => If the clouds near the surface are approx. same temperature as the land surface it can be difficult to distinguish the clouds from land. To get a clear picture of the weather you should analyse both the IR and visible images. If both images are bright in the same area => very likely that you can find a very high and thick cloud with high convective activity over that area. If you get cloud returns on a visible imagery but not on an IR image => most likely a low cloud If you get a white return on an IR imagery, along with a translucent whitish layer on a visible imagery => it is most likely a high wispy cloud - a thin layer of cirrostratus.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which choice provides the most accurate description of the meteorological feature at "T"?

key_points: Weather fronts are represented on the chart using lines, triangles and semi-circles
These fronts mark the boundaries between different air masses
A warm front is shown with a red line and red semi-circles and cold fronts are presented as blue line with blue triangles
learning.explanation: Weather fronts are represented on the chart using lines, triangles and semi-circles. These fronts mark the boundaries between different air masses. A warm front is shown with a red line and red semi-circles and cold fronts are presented as blue line with blue triangles. The simple rule is that warm air follows a warm front and cold air follows a cold front. We also see increased amounts of cloud and rainfall along the front itself. Often you will see a purple line, with purple semi-circles and triangles next to each other. These are occluded fronts, which form when faster cold fronts "catch up" with warm fronts. Sometimes these lines will be broken by crosses or contain a dot. A dot represents a front that is developing, whilst a cross tells us the front is weakening. The air trapped between a warm and cold front is called a "warm sector", and we often see low cloud and patchy, light rain associated with this type of air. You may also see thick black lines that have no semi-circles or triangles attached. These are called troughs and mark areas where the air is particularly unstable. This means that the air is quite turbulent with lots of upward motion. We tend to see showers associated with this type of feature and they don't mark any sort of boundary in the same way that a front does.

Infrared (IR). Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image. To get a clear picture of the weather you should analyse both the IR and visible images. If both images are bright in the same area => very likely that you can find a very high and thick cloud with high convective activity over that area. Note: Convective cumulus clouds develop puffy cotton shaped profiles. If you get cloud returns on a visible imagery but not on an IR image => most likely a low cloud If you get a white return on an IR imagery, along with a translucent whitish layer on a visible imagery => it is most likely a high wispy cloud - a thin layer of cirrostratus.

content.question: What is the definition of gusts?

options.A: The variation of the average wind speed.
options.B: Maximum wind speeds (gusts) and minimums (lulls) about the average wind velocity.
options.C: The average variation of the minimum wind speed.
options.D: The variation of the average peak wind speed

key_points: Gusts are instantaneous deviations from the average wind velocity
they usually last less than 20 seconds, and longer duration versions of gusts are called squalls
Gusts are included in METARs when the greatest wind speed within the last 10 minutes is more than 10 kts over the average wind speed, and this greatest speed would be quoted after the "G" in a METAR
learning.explanation: Gusts are instantaneous deviations from the average wind velocity. they usually last less than 20 seconds, and longer duration versions of gusts are called squalls. Gusts are included in METARs when the greatest wind speed within the last 10 minutes is more than 10 kts over the average wind speed, and this greatest speed would be quoted after the "G" in a METAR. The lowest wind speed (lull) is usually noted in meteorological logs but is not quoted in the METAR itself. This question is asking about the definition of a gust, and that applies to both increased wind velocities and decreased wind velocities (lulls).

content.question: For the planning of a flight with an estimated time of departure 0930 local time from an European airport a satellite picture is used to locate areas of fog. What type of satellite imagery available with observation time close to ETD does provide most likely the best information to locate these areas of fog?

options.B: Infrared (IR) and water vapour (WV), polar orbiting system
options.C: Visual (VIS) and infrared (IR), polar orbiting system

key_points: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection
There are two types of satellites; Polar Orbiting and Geostationary
Polar Orbiting satellite passes above or nearly above both poles of the body being orbited
learning.explanation: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection. There are two types of satellites; Polar Orbiting and Geostationary. Polar Orbiting satellite passes above or nearly above both poles of the body being orbited. It takes roughly 2 h to orbit the earth. This satellite orbits between 820 and 870 km above the surface and covers a band 1500 NM wide. Picture definition is good due to its relatively low orbit height – making it possible to identify fog. Geostationary satellites are put into orbit over the Equator and they take 24 hours to complete the orbit. Their orbit is considerably higher than the polar orbiting satellites (36000 km) and picture definition may not be as good, but the advantage of a continuous picture outweighs this disadvantage. Because of the Equatorial orbit the picture becomes somewhat distorted towards the poles. There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared. Visual Images. Although visual photography may be easy to interpret, it suﬀers the disadvantage of not being available continuously, due to lack of sunlight at night. Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black - Visible satellite image show solid clouds (such as CBs) as bright white and wispy clouds (thin or faint cloud - such as cirrus) as translucent whitish layers. Infrared (IR). Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image. To get a clear picture of the weather you should analyse both the IR and visible images. If both images are bright in the same area => very likely that you can find a very high and thick cloud with high convective activity over that area. If you get cloud returns on a visible imagery but not on an IR image => most likely a low cloud or fog. If you get a white return on an IR imagery, along with a translucent whitish layer on a visible imagery => it is most likely a high wispy cloud - a thin layer of cirrostratus.

learning.explanation: At 5230N 0230W, EGGP, there is a temperature inversion between 2000 ft (-2ºC) and 5000 ft (+7ºC) - where temperature increases with increasing height. There is also a Nimbostratus cloud at 3500 ft - which usually produces continuous rain, snow. Assuming that rain falls from NS clouds - generally, precipitation first falls as snow. When falling through warmer air before reaching the ground (in this case, due to the temperature inversion, temperature at 3500 ft will be above 0ºC), it melts and turns to rain droplets. Which of the following weather phenomena do the clouds over Scandinavia indicate?

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.10.01.03.05: Interpret qualitatively the satellite pictures in order to get useful information for flights: location of fronts. This is a very difficult question, as the satellite image is not very easy to read, and the region of Scandinavia is huge, and contains many different presentations of clouds on this image. Please send any exam feedback you have to us via the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. To start with, jet streams do not cause cloud. They can sometimes be associated with cirrus clouds due to the warm and cold fronts that jet streams follow, and often the location of a jet stream coincides with the location of cirrus clouds as part of those fronts. It is not a common enough effect to be able to spot jet streams on a satellite image, though. Also, the sub-tropical and arctic jet stream are usually not over the majority of Scandinavia. The arctic jet stream is a little further North when it forms, and the sub-tropical jet stream much further South. So then it is down to warm front vs cold front. Warm fronts are easier to spot because they contain quite dense clouds (particularly towards the lower levels of the front) and are usually quite uniform in shape. The clouds seen in this image are less thick, and quite patchy/isolated in sections, leading us to believe that a cold front is present, particularly running up the Eastern side of Sweden. It could actually be travelling either way, but due to normal air currents we have drawn the cold front line going from West to East. We are not too sure what is being indicated through Finland and across the border into Russia, as the satellite image is not enough alone to work out what has caused this cloud formation. We do not believe it is a warm front, as the clouds do not appear to be thick enough (if the satellite is a visible light image, which we believe it to be)

content.question: The main limitation of an infra-red image observation is:

options.A: It is not intended to identify thick and rather high clouds.
options.B: The infra-red image is based on ground observation combined with satellite returns.
options.C: It is difficult (sometimes impossible) to spot fog and/or very thin clouds such as Cirrus.
options.D: The infra-red image is unusable at night or in conditions of very low sunlight.

key_points: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection
There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared
Visual Images
learning.explanation: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection. There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared. Visual Images. Although visual photography may be easy to interpret, it suﬀers the disadvantage of not being available continuously, due to lack of sunlight at night. Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black - Visible satellite image show solid clouds (such as CBs) as bright white and wispy clouds (thin or faint cloud - such as cirrus) as translucent whitish layers. Infrared (IR). Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image => If the clouds near the surface are approx. same temperature as the land surface it can be difficult to distinguish the clouds from land. To get a clear picture of the weather you should analyse both the IR and visible images. If both images are bright in the same area => very likely that you can find a very high and thick cloud with high convective activity over that area. If you get cloud returns on a visible imagery but not on an IR image => most likely a low cloud If you get a white return on an IR imagery, along with a translucent whitish layer on a visible imagery => it is most likely a high wispy cloud - a thin layer of cirrostratus.

content.question: How can pilot reports of significant weather subsequently be used by the receiving meteorological office and their systems?

options.A: The reports can be directly used in weather prediction systems and processed into PIREPs.
options.B: The relevant Meteorological Watch Office will process the report and issue a SPECI.
options.C: The meteorological office will rebroadcast these reports because they are incompatible with digital weather processing systems.
options.D: The reports can be processed into weather models to improve subsequent forecasts.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.10.02.04.05: Explain that the gridded forecasts can be merged in information processing systems with data relayed from aircraft or pilot reports, e.g. of turbulence, to provide improved situation awareness. This question is asking about how pilot reports can actually be used by meteorologists. Not only can pilot reports (PIREPs) be relayed by ATC to inform other aircraft about potential hazards in an area, some of which are not seen by any radar or satellite imaging, but PIREPs can also be inputted into the weather models that generate future forecasts for a region. For instance, the presence of heavy clear air turbulence (CAT) in an area may not be picked up by radar or satellite (as clear air turbulence is invisible), but the pilot report of it can tell a weather model that it is occurring in that region, and it can use this information to inform its forecasted wind speeds, windshear, expected turbulence, etc. The thing to remember is that the data is still very useful, and therefore the computer program used by the meteorologists has a way to merge any pilot report data into the current model. To go through the incorrect options: "The reports can be directly used in weather prediction systems and processed into PIREPs." As mentioned above, these are already PIREPs (Pilot Reports), so the first part is correct, but there is no need to process them to make them into PIREPs. "The relevant Meteorological Watch Office will process the report and issue a SPECI." A SPECI is a special weather report for an aerodrome, they are produced when significant changes have occured since the last METAR was issued. Therefore, most pilot reports will not affect this. "The meteorological office will rebroadcast these reports because they are incompatible with digital weather processing systems." ATC may well rebroadcast the PIREPs (pilot reports) to other pilots who might be affected, but they are compatible with weather processing systems, as explained above. "The reports can be processed into weather models to improve subsequent forecasts." This is correct. As previously explained, this data is very useful for weather models and weather forecasting, so the Meteorological Watch Office can input them into the computer models.

com, thank you! Tropical Cyclone Advisory Information - Form of the code 1- Identification group: The report starts with the term "TC ADVISORY", which indicates that it is a tropical cyclone advisory
learning.explanation: Note: We have very little feedback for this question, so the TC advisory in the exam is likely to be quite different from the one seen here, but the format should be somewhat the same. Please send as much feedback as you can remember to the comments, or email it to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Tropical Cyclone Advisory Information - Form of the code 1- Identification group: The report starts with the term "TC ADVISORY", which indicates that it is a tropical cyclone advisory. 2- Date and time of the issuance (abbreviated as "DTG"): The year, month, day, hours and minutes of the issuance are reported in UTC as "yyyymmdd/GGggZ". 3- Name of the TCAC (abbreviated as "TCAC"): The name of the TCAC that issued the report is given in a free text form. 4- Name of the tropical cyclone (abbreviated as "TC"): The name, or number of the cyclone is given. 5- Advisory number (abbreviated as NR): This number starts with "01" and increase with each cyclone in the season. 6- Observed position of the centre (abbreviated as "OBS PSN"): Geographical coordinates of the centre of the tropical cyclone given in degrees and minutes. 7- Direction and speed of the movement (abbreviated as "MOV"): If the tropical ccylone moves slowly (moving at a speed lower than 3 kt), or it is stationary (moving at a speed lower than 1 kt), the abbreviations SLW or STNR are used, respectively. 8 - Intensity change (abbreviated as "INTST CHANGE"): This appears to be optional. If there is a definite change in intensity, it will be shown here; INTSF, NC, etc. 9- Atmospheric pressure of the centre (abbreviated as "C"): Given in units of hPa. 10- Maximum surface wind (abbreviated as "MAX WIND") The maximum value of the surface wind near the centre over a 10 minute time period. 11- Forecast of the position of the centre and maximum wind (abbreviated as "FCST PSN" and "FCST MAX WIND"): This information is reported 6, 12, 18 and 24 hours after the time of observation. (Not present on this extract) 12- Remarks (abbreviated as "RMK"). (Not present on this extract) 13- The code "NXT MSG EXP" indicates the date of the issuance of the next advisory. (Not present on this extract) The report ends with an equal sign. Most of the statements are pretty obviously correct with the decode above (1, 2, and 4). Using the annex, we can see that the coordinates N2706 W07306 are off the East coast of Florida (quite far off the coast, but it never asked about distance), so statement 3 is correct. Statement 5 uses km/h instead of kts, so is incorrect. Again, we have no idea about quite a lot of the content of this question, only the type of question. Learn the code above and be ready to decode a different TC advisory.

key_points: Note: This question is similar to Q501780, and we think that this question is more likely to show up in a real exam

learning.explanation: Note: This question is similar to Q501780, and we think that this question is more likely to show up in a real exam. Whilst in the first half of the flight, the aircraft is in sector "D" of the chart. This sector shows isolated scattered/broken cumulus and stratocumulus - with moderate icing to the East of the sector, we are in the West of the sector so that does not affect us. We can expect moderate turbulence at 3 000 ft for this section of flight, but no icing. In the second half of flight, we pass through sector "B" which has an occluded front followed by a slow moving cold/warm front reversal, so many different weather conditions can be expected in this area. In terms of icing, sector "B" contains cumulus and stratocumulus clouds which are overcast in the frontal areas between cloud bases of 1 500-3 000ft and tops of 5 000 - 8 000ft. The 0ºC level in sector "B" is between 4 000 ft and 6 000 ft, which could make the aircraft in non-icing conditions, however, convective activity such as that associated with fronts in this region can cause air movements that reduce the 0⁰C isotherm, and can cause icing in our case. Also, NASA quotes ice as being worst between +2⁰C and -20⁰C, so we know it can happen in low positive temperatures. The aircraft cannot therefore avoid icing conditions on that route at any of the given levels. Note: There is some debate over whether the aircraft could remain outside of icing conditions at 3 500 ft, as that is lower than the 0ºC isotherm in the B region, however, the CU/SC cloud that would be encountered does include moderate icing and turbulence, and icing can occur just above 0ºC, so we are agreeing with the most recent feedback that 3500 ft would not be able to avoid moderate icing.
