content.question: The units of measurement used for RVR are…

options.A: Metres (m) or/and Feet (ft), at discretion of ATC.
options.B: Metres (m) or/and Feet (ft) or/and statute mile, as per ICAO.
options.C: Metres (m) or/and Feet (ft), as per ICAO requirements.
options.D: Metres (m) or/and Feet (ft), according to Annex 3.

key_points: Learning Objective 050
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 050.10.01.01.11: List the units used for runway visual range (m, ft). This is one of three very similar questions (505494, 506338 and 507458). This is the least commonly reported, which is good as it is the most questionable, as discussed below. ICAO annex 3 defines RVR as follows: Runway visual range (RVR). The range over which the pilot of an aircraft on the centre line of a runway can see the runway surface markings or the lights delineating the runway or identifying its centre line. In METARs, the RVR values are prefixed by the letter “R”, followed by the runway number for which the RVR value applies and the actual RVR value. In annex 3, ICAO specifically dictate that RVR should be measured in metres, but some countries (like the USA) may choose to differ from this as long as they notify ICAO as such. For instance, The United States FAA dictate that there, RVR shall be measured in feet and reported in 100 ft intervals. ICAO requirements are just that the ICAO member states either follow the SARPs described in the annexes, or that they inform ICAO and publish the differences from the SARPs (within reason, of course). Therefore, we think it possible to say that ICAO requirements allow RVR to be reported in both Metres and Feet (though statute miles would be a push as that unit is too large to be useful in RVR measurements).

content.question:
A pilot is about to line up on the runway. ATC provides the Runway Visual Range. This indicates the range at which the pilot can do which of the following?
1. See the runway surface markings.
2. Locate the precision approach path indicators.
3. Confirm the runway designator.
4. Clearly see six centre line lights.
5. See the lights delineating the runway.
6. Identify the runway centre line.

key_points: RVR is a special measure of visibility in the direction of the runway

As prevailing visibility is usually used, which is approximately the average visibility in all directions from the station, this can be a bit inaccurate, as the visibility can vary massively between two different directions, due to different density of obscuration, perhaps

This is why, when the visibility is below 1500 m, the RVR is reported also, as the RVR (Runway Visual Range) is a measure of the exact visibility directly down the runway, and usually is measured at 3 different places on the runway, touchdown zone, midpoint, and stop-end
learning.explanation: RVR is a special measure of visibility in the direction of the runway. As prevailing visibility is usually used, which is approximately the average visibility in all directions from the station, this can be a bit inaccurate, as the visibility can vary massively between two different directions, due to different density of obscuration, perhaps. This is why, when the visibility is below 1500 m, the RVR is reported also, as the RVR (Runway Visual Range) is a measure of the exact visibility directly down the runway, and usually is measured at 3 different places on the runway, touchdown zone, midpoint, and stop-end. This is almost always higher than the prevailing visibility, as it only has to consider the visibility in one direction. These days, it is automatically measured by devices alongside the runway, called transmissometers (the newer versions are called scatterometers). In terms of this question, the runway visual range is often measured by counting the amount of centreline markings or lights that can be seen ahead of the aircraft, so the answer "identify the runway centre line" must be correct. Also, the next closest answer is "see the lights delineating the runway", which you should be able to see also. The other options are either to the side of the runway (in a direction where visibility is not assured), or behind the aircraft when lined up.

content.question: What is a radiosonde?

options.A: Equipment used for determining upper winds (velocity and direction) by transmitting different radio waves and measuring the amount of the reflected waves by the moving air. These values correlate to the speed and direction of the wind.
options.B: A meteorological station on ground or water at which measurements of meteorological variables are made automatically and a radio transmitter sends automatically this information to a meteorological centre. These data from such a station are indicated in a METAR by the term auto.
options.C: Equipment used for determining upper winds only (velocity and direction) by tracking a free balloon by electronic means at the observing station.
options.D: Instrument intended to be carried by a balloon up through the atmosphere, equipped with devices to measure meteorological variables and provided with a radio transmitter for sending this information to the observing station.

key_points: A radiosonde is a battery-powered instrument carried into the atmosphere usually by a weather balloon that measures various atmospheric parameters and transmits them by radio to a ground receiver
As the radiosonde is carried aloft it measures pressure, temperature, and relative humidity
Its rate of climb is 1200 fpm and maximum ceiling between 65 000 and 115 000 ft
learning.explanation: A radiosonde is a battery-powered instrument carried into the atmosphere usually by a weather balloon that measures various atmospheric parameters and transmits them by radio to a ground receiver. As the radiosonde is carried aloft it measures pressure, temperature, and relative humidity. Its rate of climb is 1200 fpm and maximum ceiling between 65 000 and 115 000 ft.

content.question: A METAR reports a visibility of 8 km. Added to the report is a "BECMG 4000". What can you expect to happen to the visibility?

options.A: Improve from 4 000 m to 8 000 m in the next 2 hours.
options.C: Decrease to 4 km within the next 2 hours.

key_points: METAR and SPECI are observations of actual weather conditions
When a change is expected to occur within the next 2 hours, the trend forecast shall begin with one of the change indicators "BECMG" or "TEMPO": TEMPO
Temporary change between the specified period
learning.explanation: METAR and SPECI are observations of actual weather conditions. When a change is expected to occur within the next 2 hours, the trend forecast shall begin with one of the change indicators "BECMG" or "TEMPO": TEMPO. Temporary change between the specified period. After the end of the period, the weather will revert back to the state of the last definitive change BECMG. Gradual change from a previous state to a new one between the specified periods. After the end of the period, the weather will be the described one, nullifying previous changes. "BECMG 4000" => visibility will become 4 000 m within the next 2 hours. ICAO Annex 3 Appendix 5 1.3.4 Recommendation.- The change indicator "BECMG" and the associated time group should be used to describe changes where the meteorological conditions are expected to reach or pass through specified threshold values at a regular or irregular rate and at an unspecified time during the time period. The time period should normally not exceed 2 hours but in any case should not exceed 4 hours.

content.question: A flight is due to depart from Heathrow (EGLL) at 00:15 local time. The pilot wishes to watch satellite imagery to determine the weather situation on the route. Which type of imagery should be used?

key_points: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection
There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared
Visible imagery is produced by the sun's rays reflecting off of clouds - which means that it is not available continuously, due to the lack of sunlight at night
learning.explanation: SATELLITE IMAGERY Cloud detection. There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared. Visible imagery is produced by the sun's rays reflecting off of clouds - which means that it is not available continuously, due to the lack of sunlight at night. Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black. Infrared imagery is produced by sensing the emitted radiation coming off of clouds. The temperature of the cloud will determine the wavelength of radiation emitted from the cloud. Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image. With regards to this question, note that this is a night flight. As above discussed, at night, due to lack of sunlight, visible images are not available. Therefore, the weather picture which shall be used is the infrared imagery, which is available 24 h a day.

content.question: What are the images of satellites provided daily by the weather service used for?

options.A: To measure wind currents on the ground
options.D: To locate fronts in areas with few observation stations

key_points: SATELLITE IMAGES, in meteorology, are primarily used to monitor the weather and climate of the Earth
Satellite images can often be used to help meteorologists forecasting the weather over the next 12, 24 and 36 hours
These will usually show the cloud patterns over an area
learning.explanation: SATELLITE IMAGES, in meteorology, are primarily used to monitor the weather and climate of the Earth. Satellite images can often be used to help meteorologists forecasting the weather over the next 12, 24 and 36 hours. These will usually show the cloud patterns over an area. For example, a swirl of white cloud on an infrared satellite image often means that a depression is moving in. Satellites can be Polar Orbiting, covering the entire Earth and passing above or nearly above both poles, or Geostationary satellites, hovering over the Equator. There are two methods of producing the weather picture; visual photography and infrared. => Apart from clouds and fog, satelite imagery can be used to identify other weather phenomenon, such as Low Pressure Systems and Fronts. Weather satellite images have also helped in monitoring volcanic ash clouds.

key_points: TAF: Terminal Aerodrome Forecasts are forecasts of meteorological conditions at an aerodrome, as opposed to the report of actual, present conditions as given in a METAR
TAF 240600Z 2407/2416 VRB02KT CAVOK= VRB02KT: Wind variable 2 kt, VRB used when wind speed < 3 kt CAVOK: abbreviation for “cloud, ceiling and visibility are OK
” There are four criteria which must be met in order for CAVOK to appear in METARs or TAFs
learning.explanation: TAF: Terminal Aerodrome Forecasts are forecasts of meteorological conditions at an aerodrome, as opposed to the report of actual, present conditions as given in a METAR. TAF 240600Z 2407/2416 VRB02KT CAVOK= VRB02KT: Wind variable 2 kt, VRB used when wind speed < 3 kt CAVOK: abbreviation for “cloud, ceiling and visibility are OK.” There are four criteria which must be met in order for CAVOK to appear in METARs or TAFs. These are: the visibility must be 10 kilometers or more; the height of the lowest cloud must be no less than 5000 ft, or the level of highest minimum sector altitude, whichever is the greater; there must be no cumulonimbus or ‘towering cumulus’ (TCU) present; there must be no significant weather at or in the vicinity of the aerodrome. VOLMET: The purpose of a VOLMET broadcast is to provide weather information to aircraft in flight. VOLMET: 0920Z 13012KT 8000 SCT040CB BKN100 20/18 Q1015 TEMPO TS 13012KT: Mean wind direction and mean wind speed 8000: Visibility 8000 m SCT040CB: Scattered CB clouds at 4000 ft TEMPO TS: Temporary thunderstorms As we can see, the forecast and actual observation differ quite significantly.

key_points: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through
Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs
The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation
learning.explanation: WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through. Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs. The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation. In simple words, Radar attenuation is simply the absorption or reflection of radar signals as the radar pulse penetrates an area of precipitation, preventing that radar from detecting any additional cells that lie behind the first storm. Tip for avoiding shadows: To accurately interpret your radar returns, aim the tilt on your radar down far enough to paint the ground, then look for returns. If you see a potential shadow (a dark, blank area), look for a cell in front of the shadow. If you see a storm before the shadow, avoid it. If you don’t see any storm cells in front of the dark area, it’s probably not a shadow, but may be a large lake or a tall mountain (equally disturbing, depending on your altitude).

content.question: The type of information given by airborne weather radar is a map with an indication of..

key_points: AIRBORNE WEATHER RADAR Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it
It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail)

learning.explanation: AIRBORNE WEATHER RADAR Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail). Therefore, do not try to use it to avoid instrument weather associated with clouds and fog – it does not provide any assurance of avoiding IFR weather conditions. A knowledge of the radar principle is paramount in order to accurately tune this system and interpret the weather radar display correctly. Reflectivity Weather detection is based on the reflectivity of water droplets. The weather echo appears on the Navigation Display (ND) with a color scale that goes from red (high reflectivity) to green (low reflectivity). The weather radar echo returns vary in intensity as a function of the droplet size, composition and quantity. For example, a water particle is five times more reflective than an ice particle of the same size.

content.question: How is an easterly wave identifiable on a surface weather chart?

learning.explanation: An Easterly wave, sometimes also referred to as Tropical wave, is a wave or trough of low pressure, originating over West Africa between latitude 5° North and 20° North and moving towards the Caribbean. Some of the waves proceed beyond the Caribbean and into the Pacific. They occur during the summer and autumn, usually numbering about 50 each year. The waves have a typical wavelength of 2 000 to 2 500 km and a life span of 1-2 weeks. The weather produced will be like that associated with tropical revolving storms, though to a much lesser extent in severity. Towards the west and the Equator unstable conditions will dominate, with cloudy, showery weather. Easterly waves may develop into tropical revolving storms themselves.

learning.explanation: Wind velocity in a METAR is stated as the measured or estimated mean of each component over the 10 minutes prior to the time of issue of the METAR, unless there are significant variations during this 10 minute period. content.question: While using the airborne weather radar in order to circumnavigate thunderstorms, the radar scope is clear between heavy echoes. Which of the following interpretations of the scope is correct?

options.A: The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received because the number of cloud droplets is too small to generate a significant echo. Thus, the pilot will have a good visual sight of the thunderstorm clouds.
options.B: The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received. However, this radar scope provides no assurance of being in VMC while flying in this area.
options.C: The clear area indicates an area from which no echoes are received. An aircraft flying in this area will be in VMC due to the absence of precipitation drops.
options.D: This is a typical radar scope from which the region of clear air turbulence between thunderstorm clouds can be detected.

key_points: The question describes WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through
Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs
The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation
learning.explanation: The question describes WEATHER ATTENUATION The weather radar display depends on signal returns: the more intense the precipitation, the less distance the radar can see through. Therefore when the radar echo is unable to make the two way trip through heavy precipitation, a "shadowing" effect occurs. The stronger the rainstorm, the more radar energy will be scattered by Weather Attenuation. In simple words, Radar attenuation is simply the absorption or reflection of radar signals as the radar pulse penetrates an area of precipitation, preventing that radar from detecting any additional cells that lie behind the first storm. Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation. Therefore, do not try to use it to avoid instrument weather associated with clouds and fog – it does not provide any assurance of avoiding IFR weather conditions. Furthermore, as discussed above, Airborne Weather radar detects large droplet precipitation and hail (present in CBs), it does not detect stratus/stratocumulus or very small water droplets => making it relatively easy to identify embedded cumulonimbus.

content.question: By use of Doppler techniques, modern airborne weather radar can detect turbulence in..

key_points: AIRBORNE WEATHER RADAR Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it
It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail)
Reflectivity Weather detection is based on the reflectivity of water droplets
learning.explanation: AIRBORNE WEATHER RADAR Airborne weather radar is designed for avoiding severe weather, not for penetrating it. It detects drops of precipitation (such as rain/snow/hail). Reflectivity Weather detection is based on the reflectivity of water droplets. The weather echo appears on the Navigation Display (ND) with a color scale that goes from red (high reflectivity) to green (low reflectivity). The weather radar echo returns vary in intensity as a function of the droplet size, composition and quantity. => Airborne weather radars do not detect turbulence, although turbulent air, particularly within a thunderstorm, often contains water. In some modern radars, a change in frequency (a Doppler shift) in the reflected (returned) radar signal caused by moving precipitation is measured and is used to give an indication of likely turbulence. => This function (the TURB function) is based on the Doppler effect and is sensitive to precipitation movement. The TURB function is on most weather radars only active within a range of 40 NM (Doppler measurement capability) and should only be used in wet turbulence.

learning.explanation: Visual Images. Although visual photography may be easy to interpret, it suﬀers the disadvantage of not being available continuously, due to lack of sunlight at night. Clouds will appear white, the land grey and the sea black - Visible satellite image show solid clouds (such as CBs) as bright white and wispy clouds (thin or faint cloud - such as cirrus) as translucent whitish layers. Infrared (IR). Infrared images have the advantage of being available for 24 hours a day and the shading of the picture will be more or less the same by day and by night. Cold (high) cloud will give a white image, lower cloud a somewhat darker one, whilst warm land will give a dark image. To get a clear picture of the weather you should analyse both the IR and visible images. If both images are bright in the same area => very likely that you can find a very high and thick cloud with high convective activity over that area. If you get cloud returns on a visible imagery but not on an IR image => most likely a low cloud If you get a white return on an IR imagery, along with a translucent whitish layer on a visible imagery => it is most likely a high wispy cloud - a thin layer of cirrostratus.

content.question:
Refer to figure.
Which of the following positions represents a cold front?

key_points: Z ⇒ occluded front
T ⇒ warm front
Y ⇒ cold front
learning.explanation: Z ⇒ occluded front. T ⇒ warm front. Y ⇒ cold front. Weather fronts are represented on the chart using lines, triangles and semi-circles. These fronts mark the boundaries between different air masses. A warm front is shown with a red line and red semi-circles and cold fronts are presented as blue line with blue triangles. The simple rule is that warm air follows a warm front and cold air follows a cold front. We also see increased amounts of cloud and rainfall along the front itself. Often you will see a purple line, with purple semi-circles and triangles next to each other. These are occluded fronts, which form when faster cold fronts "catch up" with warm fronts. Sometimes these lines will be broken by crosses or contain a dot. A dot represents a front that is developing, whilst a cross tells us the front is weakening. The air trapped between a warm and cold front is called a "warm sector", and we often see low cloud and patchy, light rain associated with this type of air. You may also see thick black lines that have no semi-circles or triangles attached. These are called troughs and mark areas where the air is particularly unstable. This means that the air is quite turbulent with lots of upward motion. We tend to see showers associated with this type of feature and they don't mark any sort of boundary in the same way that a front does.

content.question: An aircraft encounters atmospheric conditions in which abrupt changes of attitude and altitude of the aircraft occur. Changes in accelerometer readings go up to 1.2 g measured at the aircraft`s centre of gravity. Lose objects inside the aircraft are tossed about. Which report, if any, is required?

key_points: ICAO Doc 4444 4
12 REPORTING OF OPERATIONAL AND METEOROLOGICAL INFORMATION 4
learning.explanation: ICAO Doc 4444 4.12 REPORTING OF OPERATIONAL AND METEOROLOGICAL INFORMATION 4.12.3 Contents of special air-reports 4.12.3.1 Special air-reports shall be made by all aircraft whenever the following conditions are encountered or observed: a) moderate or severe turbulence; or b) moderate or severe icing; or c) severe mountain wave; or d) thunderstorms, without hail that are obscured, embedded, widespread or in squall lines; or e) thunderstorms, with hail that are obscured, embedded, widespread or in squall lines; or f) heavy duststorm or heavy sandstorm; or g) volcanic ash cloud; or h) pre-eruption volcanic activity or a volcanic eruption. Note.— Pre-eruption volcanic activity in this context means unusual and/or increasing volcanic activity which could presage a volcanic eruption. In addition, in the case of transonic and supersonic flight: i) moderate turbulence; or j) hail; or k) cumulonimbus clouds. ICAO defines 4 levels of turbulence intensity, light, moderate, severe and extreme. In very basic terms, 0 - 0.5 G of acceleration is light, 0.5 - 1 G is moderate, 1 - 1.5 G is severe, and anything above that is extreme turbulence. As this scenario fits the criteria for severe turbulence (1.2 G accelerations), a mandatory special air report shall be made by the pilot. There are other criteria for turbulence classification, but this is the easiest one to identify for this question.

content.question:
A pre-flight weather briefing must be prepared, and information is needed on the expected weather at the destination for an arrival approximately 3 hours later. Which of the following, available from meteorological services during flight planning, can provide this information?
1. The TAF covering the estimated time of arrival.
2. The current ATIS message promulgated by the destination airport.
3. NOTAMS in force at the estimated time of arrival.
4. The latest METAR (giving particular scrutiny to any trend information).
5. Aerodrome warnings in force at the estimated time of arrival.
6. The current VOLMET information promulgated by the destination airport.
7. The Significant Weather Chart covering the area of the destination airport valid at the estimated time of arrival.
8. Relevant SIGMET information valid at the estimated time of arrival.

key_points: The TAF covering the estimated time of arrival
CORRECT
learning.explanation: 1. The TAF covering the estimated time of arrival. CORRECT. We will need the TAF covering our arrival time. 2. The current ATIS message promulgated by the destination airport. INCORRECT. Current ATIS will be outdated upon arrival. 3. NOTAMS in force at the estimated time of arrival. INCORRECT. We do not need NOTAM as we are looking for expect weather - such information isn't included in NOTAMs. 4. The latest METAR (giving particular scrutiny to any trend information). CORRECT. Even though the latest METAR will be outdated, it is still useful to compare its trend with the TAF. 5. Aerodrome warnings in force at the estimated time of arrival. CORRECT. Should be taken into consideration as they include on strong winds, thunderstorms, snow etc. 6. The current VOLMET information promulgated by the destination airport. INCORRECT. VOLMET is for aircraft in flight and not for pre flight. 7. The Significant Weather Chart covering the area of the destination airport valid at the estimated time of arrival. CORRECT. Contains infor regarding icing, turbulence, CBs associated with thunderstorms, etc. 8. Relevant SIGMET information valid at the estimated time of arrival. CORRECT. CORRECT. Provides info on TS, SEV TURB/ICING, etc. Therefore, correct option is 1, 4, 5, 7 and 8.

learning.explanation: ICAO Annex 3 Appendix 3 4.4.2.3 b) Obscurations (hydrometeors) Fog (FG) - Reported when visibility is less than 1 000 m, except when qualified by "MI", "BC", "PR" or "VC" Mist (BR) - Reported when visibility is at least 1 000 m but not more than 5 000 m. 4.4.2.6 (.) Shallow (MI) - Less than 2 m (6 ft) above ground level.
